  1. does not shed like the drug store cheap ones. I do hang it in a brush holder so the handle doesn't rot.
  2. I purchased this brush about a month ago and use it regularly. Overall it is an OK brush given the price (brushes can go over $100). I expected the brush to lose some hairs for the first 10 shaves or so, but this one seems to constantly lose hairs. It is still very usable - but I worry if within the next few months it may become too depleted.<br /><br />Anyhow - I use the brush with Proraso Shaving Soap. It makes a nice lather to then shave with a DE razor. When creating the lather, I only use the tips of the brush, so no hard pushing to overuse and wear it out sooner than it should.<br /><br />Overall - I give this 3 stars. If it does lose too many hairs, I will try a different brush my next time around.
  3. I received a tweezerman brush several years ago as a gift, and enjoyed it for its stiff bristles. I recently order another, and was disappointed that the bristles are limp and the brush was not as thick.
  4. softest brush i have owned and it holds up well to regular use. Creates a nice smooth consistent lather every time!!!

  21. I have been using this brush now for about 2 months. On average I shave 2-3 times per week. I have thoroughly enjoyed this product and would recommend it to anyone. This is the first shaving brush I have ever owned and it is a great introduction. It is affordable and durable. There is barely any sign of use. As with any kind of product like this it is important that you take the time to learn proper care for it to last. If you do that I have no doubt that this brush will last a good long time for anyone.

  24. I've been wet shaving for more than three years now. I decided to upgrade from my cheap Omega silk (seta) brush [[ASIN:B000JXY8MO Omega 46065 Shaving Set with Brush, Holder, and Soap in Bowl]] with this Tweezerman badger brush. The Tweezerman is coarse on my face and shed like crazy on the very FIRST use as well as subsequent uses. I know how to use and care for a brush, and this one is a real disappointment. Even when I first started wet shaving using the Omega silk brush, before knowing how to care for it, the Omega seldom shed more than a hair or two every now and then. Maybe I just got a bad unit from Tweezerman, but even if that's the case, it speaks to poor quality control. I would pass on this one.
  25. I've been using this brush now for quite a few weeks. I am very pleased at the quality and quantity of lather produced. There were quite a few hairs shed early on, but that seems to have stopped now. For the price, this simply cannot be beaten. It's now my every day brush.
  26. the first few days there will probably be some loss of the hair. perhaps 3 or 4 shaves at most.<br />then it is great - I have it almost a month.

  28. Exactly what I expected. Quality is great and at a great price. I've seen brushed in stores for 3x the price.
  29. I bought this brush as a replacement for another, that I can't seem to find, after I moved.<br /><br />I have other Tweezerman products and they seem to be fairly high quality products. This brush is no exception.<br /><br />It is a badger brush with a wooden handle. The bristles are about 2 inches long and the width is approximately 2 1/2 inches at its widest. It is not a really soft brush, I would say more like a medium texture.<br /><br />In use, the brush is able to be wetted and hold water quite well. I'm able to work up a lather in a short time. On average it loses about four - five bristles per week.<br /><br />It is clean rinsing and dries well if you hang it upside down or lay it on its side.<br /><br />Even for a budget brush I would not hesitate to purchase it.<br /><br />UPDATE 6/17/2010: This brush is still going strong after 1 year of shaving. I have a brush stand that I use to let it dry upside down. All of the bristles are still there, and the handle looks like new!
  30. Update 2014<br />It has been about 5 years since I purchased this brush, and it is still going strong. I use it every day. Well worth the $10.<br /><br />Original review 2009<br />To get a 100% badger brush for 10 dollars is a steal. It's not high quality badger hair, but its still a very nice brush for the price. No problems so far. Hair loss on the brush is minimal. Just store properly (Bristles facing down) and take care of it and your 10 dollar investment will last you a long time.
  31. Mine was made with inferior glue.....a bristle came loose every time I used it, now ( after 5 months use) the entire bristle pack popped out of the handle.....the wood is cracked! It was nice to look at, and worked OK. These are hand assembled, you might get a good one. I will probably epoxy it back together and get some more use out of it. My last cheap, plastic mass produced shave brush lasted 15 years and never lost bristles, they just wore down to nubs!
  32. No \\"shedding\\" so far. Only brush I've ever tried, for $ I'm satisfied. Holds enough water to get a good lather going. update: @12 shaves lost first hair, but is holding up since. expecting to get at least 6-9 months out of the brush, with almost daily usage. time will tell.
  33. This brush is one of the cheaper ones that I have seen in the market. I have been using it for a few months. I like it mostly. Initially, I thought a lot of hairs separated from the brush, but that has slowed down now. It DOES hold more moisture and lather than a synthetic hair brush, but could hold much more. Buy it if you want a cheaper version of the badger brush OR are just starting out on the \\"old-school\\" double-edge shaving approach. Otherwise, if you consider yourself to be an expert, buy a better one
  34. I am new to DE shaving, so I didn't want to invest too much initially. Along with my Merkur razor, I purchased the Tweezerman Brush, and I'm impressed with its quality. Badger hair brushes can, apparently, cost well into the hundreds of dollars, so I wasn't expecting much for 15 bucks, but this is a good little brush. I get a good lather for my shaves and the badger hairs stay in place, for the most part. The only thing missing is a stand, which would really come in handy for drying, but for $15, you couldn't really ask for more!
  35. The brush is excellent and works quite well. It would fit my hand better if the handle was a little longer, but it was an excellent buy for the price.

  37. It's a great brush for new wetshavers to get themselves started. It's cheap but it performs well considering it's price. My only complaint is it seems fragile. When I first ordered the brush, it was sent to me cracked, but was replaced immediately once I contacted the vendor.
  38. This is a good brush at a price that seems cheap by comparison to other brushes. I read reviews that questioned the product's durability. The key is to rinse well, shake as dry as you can and store bristle-side down. It seems to work. There are numerous shaving enthusiasts and like all enthusiasms, the opportunities to spend money are endless. This is a economical way to experience wet shaving. You can always spend more...but do it later.
  39. I really like this brush and would recommend it. I've been using it for several months now. It provides a firm but soft application on the face and lathers up very well. I do find that it holds lather and water much better than the cheap one I bought at the grocery store. It did smell slightly at first but I just rinsed it out with cold water a couple of times and let it air out on its side. The smell went away. I have lost very, very few bristles on this brush. I clean it out with cold water after each shave, shake it out well and store it on its side. I'm quite happy with this purchase and would recommend it to friends.
  40. Bought this a few weeks ago along with a safety razor, soap dish, blades, and razor and brush stand.   46. I recently converted over from using everything from the generic foams or gels to using shaving soap and a badger brush. Although I can tell you that this method of shaving is far superior; I would stay away from this particular brush. The set of bristles came off of the wooden base on the first shave. This happened as I was trying to squeeze the soap out of the brush (picture squeezing a tube of toothpaste) on my second pass of shaving. If you do end up buying this product, just hold on to the base of the bristles when you do this and you may be fine. However glue is what holds the bunch of bristles together on the wooden base where I would have preferred more of a mechanical attachment (such as a metal ring with teeth) in addition to the glue. -Rene N.
  47. Good quality brush. Much better than the drug store boars hair brush that was falling apart. The brush produces a very smooth shaving foam, much less coarse than boars hair.

Krebs look is ever in style, I may stop shaving, but for now, I shave.<br /><br />So I figured I'd start with a bowl, some soap, and a low-price range brush ($60 seems awfully high to me, some of them go to $120- $200 and up).<br /><br />I used this for a week.   53. I bought this brush when I first began DE shaving about 6 months ago and used it for the first 3.5 months. I never had any problems with the handle. It's still fine. There was some moderate shedding at the beginning, which is to be expected. Lathers up ok. Water retention isn't bad either. The thing I don't like is that it's too scratchy, even after having broken in, which didn't take long (a few uses). It's not horribly scratchy, but it is enough to where I never use it anymore now that I have a couple of brushes that are better quality (and more expensive - Semogue 1305 boar and Parker Silvertip badger). Granted, the Tweezerman's a cheap badger brush, and if you just have NO money, I suppose it's ok... maybe. I wouldn't recommend it, though. It might be kind of difficult to get better quality than this at its low price, but I think spending a little more on a better brush, even for a beginner, is definitely the way to go.
  54. I love this brush and have been using it pretty much everyday for two years now. First, if you're thinking of switching to a shaving brush, do it for sure! It is well made and fairly inexpensive for what you're getting. I do have bristles that are periodically coming out, but I think that's to be expected. The important things is how long it has lasted me so far and how great it feels to use. I'd highly recommend to anyone.

  58. I was a little upset to say that...i pulled it out the package in 2 pieces. Not enough glue on the brush to keep to the handle. It was quite an upset to be honest.   59. Arrived without proper gluing which caused it to fall apart in the first shave. Went ahead and glued it myself with some dollar store super glue and hasn't fallen apart since. However, due to it's original construction it continues to lose hairs and will likely be unusable soon. Should have trusted the other reviews that mentioned the same thing. For those that will say \\"Did you use a brush holder?\\" - It broke right after I pulled it out of the package for my first shave. Never even had a chance to shave with it before it did.
  60. This brush was the first one I purchased for my DE shaving setup. It works well and lathers many different soaps and cremes well. I have compared it to a Semogue 1305 and it does out perform it. That might be possibly because the Semogue 1305 has not been broken in yet.
  61. I was very skeptical purchasing this brush due to the inexpensive price. I must say it has greatly surpassed any brush I've eve used, and for a quarter the price! Holds a crazy amount of lather and is every thing you want in a high quality brush. It's bristles are soft and the knot is very durable(haven't lost a single bristle).My only gripe is I hadn't found this deal sooner.
  62. Upon arrival the brush is much larger than I had anticipated. During the first use, I did have to pull one or two bristles off my face, but other than that - it exfoliates really well and doesn't feel cheap. The amount of bristles make the brush very wide and they are almost too firm - but I imagine the more I use it, the more comfortable it will become. All in all, if you're looking for a brush that does what it's supposed to and you aren't incredibly concerned with how fancy it is - this is it! The price it right.
  63. My brush is still not 100% broke in yet. It does loose a few hairs here and there, but again it is a new brush. It lathers much better than boars hair, and is MUCH nicer to your skin. For the price I think the Tweezerman brush is top notch all the way. Yes you can spend alot more on brushes, and in the future I probably will, but as a beginner to traditional type shaving this brush performs very well
  64. I shaved using this product twice. I picked it up to begin a shave, and the brush head fell out on the floor. It's very solidly built like products at 2-3 times the price. Very few hairs fell out while using it as compared to cheaper ones where you are constantly picking hairs off your face.   70. I bought this item after being \\"treated\\" by my family to a more expensive line of \\"art\\"-istic shaving gear (their cheapest brush, the one I have, is $55, and you can spend up to $1200). I got hooked on the experience of using a brush after years of foams that left me with razor bumps and irritated skin. The brush isn't the singular answer to this problem, but it helps. I got the \\"Tweezerman\\" based pretty much on price, and that is was a badger hair brush (there is a difference between badger hair and synthetic, for sure). I wanted to have a brush I could take with me on trips, and leave the other one at home. This brush is at least as good as the original brush I have. It holds water well and makes great lather. Get this one - can't beat it for the price.
  71. Damn fine brush for a good price. Very functional. Works well under nominal and field conditions. Bristles are just right and work up a good lather. Facilitates a good close shave, even for those with a barbed wire like beard.
  72. I have been using a mug and brush ever since I was \\"old\\" enough to think shaving everyday was going to be the coolest thing going. Ever since canned shave cream and electric shavers have made old mug and brush shaving something more nostalgic in nature than a real marketable item, shaving mugs, brushes, and soaps have evolved into something far more often ornate and decorative than useful. There used to be some cheap plastic brushes available in some local drug stores but they are fast drying up. On the other end, I have seen outrageous prices asked for fancy ones on some places online. This Tweezerman is all the shaver you will ever need at a very reasonable price. Its solid wood, and the bristles are big and just the right stiffness. (Since all brushes get softer over use, its not a good idea to start off with softer ones.) Although all brushes lose some of their bristles during regular use, this brush is losing them at what I would call a very reasonable rate. I don't own what Tweezerman refers too as their \\"deluxe\\" brush. However take it from someone that has always shaved with a mug and brush, and can \\"almost\\" remember the time when that was all there was, this is an excellent quality brush which should last you for many years. Buy two and you will be done for life..... Recommended.
  73. i had to break down and replace the antique shaving brush that i had of my grandfathers, and i couldn't be happier, this is a great brush

And the darn thing is uncomfortable to use - a green scrubby from the kitchen is softer. It is probably the last Tweezerman's product I will try.

Badger hair is way too soft and it feels more like a mop and less like a brush. All in all I'd say badger brushes are over rated. I'd recommend this product if you want to see what badger brushes are all about but don't want to spend a fortune on a fancy one or if you already like badger brushes but want a cheap one for traveling.

Using a brush to apply a good shaving cream is the only way to go. A very enjoyable experience.

  80. This is my first badger shaving bursh, and I was not expecting much from it. Most other pure badger brushes are priced mush higher, and I could not see how this cheap of a brush would provide good quailty. Was I ever wrong. It creats lather quickly. A little stiff, but is getting softer with each use. It will shed a few hairs, but it is still a well made product. A little light in the handel, but for the price whose complaining.   81. I've gotten this brush about a month ago and it has held up pretty well. At $15 it is the best value pure badger brush on the market. At first it's a little stiff. It loses a few bristles here and there but after a few uses it breaks in. I haven't lost a bristle in weeks and its gotten softer. Of course there are better best badger brushes and silvertip badger brushes on the market but be prepared to pay $40-200 USD for a quality badger brush. The Tweezerman makes a good starter brush at $15. Why even bother to buy a synthetic or boar brush (both don't hold water well) when you can get this one for $15? I plan to upgrade to a better/softer brush down the line but the Tweezerman is treating me well and in the future will make an excellent back up or travel brush. I recommend this brush for anyone who decides to start traditional wet shaving.
  82. Can't really complain. It works as advertised. It's not as soft as more expensive brushes, but I think it lathers better.
  83. I just recently got into wet shaving and I bought this brush as my first one. I've gotta say its really nice, its a decent size and it works your cream into a lather quite nicely. My only complaints would be that the bristles could be a bit softer and since it is animal hair it smells a bit funky when you get it wet for the first few times.
  84. I have been using this shaving brush more than 4 years! Badger hair is the only way to go for a great shave, and this brush is constructed with a good grade (research the grades of badger hair used for bristles). The only issue I've had is the need to dip the handle in polyurethane about a year ago, since then it has been just like new. Tip: Always store shaving brushes with the bristles down (buy a $2 hanger), this will prevent ongoing loss of bristles.
  85. I gave this review 4 stars because this is a great investment to make to start off shaving...and much much better than your run of the mill Wal-Mart boar brush. Knot size will range from 21-23mm after the initial bloom of this brush. If youre looking for a soft badger brush with a featherlight touch...this is not it. But it will get the job done. This brush holds a decent amount of water, and will create lather pretty easily. Its a bit more difficult if you are using the shaving soap pucks for your shave. I would recommend using a shave creame with this brush. Something not from a aerosol container either...Truefitt & Hill creates a very nice cream. In closing, get this brush if youre looking for something cheap to practice lathering techniques with. If you have been involved in the world of straight shaving or double edge shaving for awhile...you should already know that youre going to get what your paying for in a 15 dollar badger brush. Happy shaving everyone
  86. There's no reason to spend more for a badger brush. I'm very happy with this purchase and would buy the brush again. I'm been using it eveyday and see no issues. The only thing you need to remember is to wipe down the wooden handle when you're done.

I'm pretty hard on stuff, even though I take care of it, and this brush is unphased by the work it does making lather, and lathering my head (I only shave my skull, not my beard) for 3 to 4 passes. I'm very happy with this brush:)

  91. I'm fairly new to the \\"wet shaving\\" scene, but I started out with a Boar's hair brush. I did not have much luck, and almost gave up. So I decided to try this brush, figuring at worst, I'm only out 13 bucks. I have not touched the boars hair brush since. I love this brush!   92. Good brush, it has lasted for a couple years now, but the bristles constantly fall out. It also had a very strong odor every time it got wet for the first few weeks of use.
  93. I bought a Tweezerman shaving brush to replace a boar bristle brush I lost--yes lost. The Tweezerman does a better job because it's more comfortable and because it lathers up faster and thicker. That said, the differences are minor in respect to the final shave. Both do a good job and the job they both do good is keeping your skin wet while you shave. The badger bristles have a slight edge in this. You'd think keeping skin wet would be easy, but it's not. What lubricates a blade more than anything is the water itself and not what's in the soap. The second you splash water on your skin it immediately begins to evaporate, so by the time you get your razor to your face most of it has evaporated. The soap foam keeps the water at your skin--that's its job here. The best shave doesn't need any soap at all. Shave under a shower with no soap and you'll see what I mean. Try it as a test. You'll get the closest shave that way. Do this only if you have memorized where everything is on your face. Shaving foam does as good a job as a wet brush in my opinion and so I use it more often than not. My final view is that the Tweezerman brush is a great deal and works well. I can see no reason to buy a more expensive brush--some sell for more than a hundred plus some dollars. Whatever they add to the mix for this price is probably not worth it. If you want to impress people with your shaving acumen, learn to use a straight razor--not for wusses or the faint of heart, though. I have been using the brush for several months and have not had any of the quality issues like shedding bristles that others here have reported, so this experience seems to vary. There could be some quality control problems at play. I do make it a point to hang the brush upside-down to dry, though. Drying it bristle side up might allow water to pool so that the glue holding the bristles is weakened.
  94. I had to purchase a second one of these to use at work. Can't beat this brush for the low price!
  95. Wow, what can I say...This is my first badger brush. It works amazing, creates a great lather, has good size and was a fantastic price! 5 Stars!
  96. This is an all badger brush, and believe me, it smells like it. You get what you pay for. I've previously used a Vulfix brush which costs a couples times more than this, but was well worth it. This brush is barely useable, the hairs are extremely prickly unlike higher quality brushes, and it smells like a dead badger!
  97. Classic shaving, wet shaving, or whatever you want to call it, is essentially the idea that older style shaving tools and techniques deliver a better shave, a better shaving experience, and/or more economy, than the modern multi-blade cartridge razor and can of shaving cream gives. Like any other pursuit or hobby, there are those that will approach it from a perspective of frugality, those who'll opt for luxury and status, and those who want to hit the sweet spot of performance for the least expense. The Tweezerman's Men's Shaving Brush aims for that last group, and hits the mark well. The whole idea here is that the Tweezerman brush is the least expensive Badger hair brush available new, and badger brushes deliver high quality lather with less time and effort than boar hair or synthetic brushes. There are certainly badger brushes to be had for several hundred dollars, and they sport a higher quality grade of badger hair, and more of it. There are cheaper brushes made of lesser material. With the Tweezerman, you get most of the performance of the luxury brush with a cost more in line with a budget brush of far lower quality. My Tweezerman performs admirably, shedding few hairs after the first use. There is little heft to the handle, and there are certainly brushes that are more pleasing to the eye. If you get the brush acquisition bug, the Tweezerman will become the Yugo in your collection of exotic cars, an object of some scorn. If you are used to a boar or synthetic brush, the Tweezerman will seem like hot stuff. If you like nice for less, the Tweezerman is a great buy, and if you treat yourself to a nicer brush later, you'll have a handy travel brush in the Tweezerman. This little brush has been part of the routine that has transformed the necessary drudgery of shaving to an enjoyable time in the day that I actually look forward to. Not bad for a few bucks.
  98. I was all ready to buy this brush until I got to checkout. The standard shipping to a US address was within a dollar of the cost of the brush itself. There are many other places online to find this brush with far less onerous shipping costs.
  99. I saw this item an was skeptical at first, Seeing the price compared to others I've seen. But to my surprised this brush works like a charm! You get a real thick foam built up,holds lotsa moisture! and I have had no shedding,it's a great buy!
  100. Is this a good brush? It made lather and put it on my face. I don't see what more I could need. It was stiffer than I expected, but for all I know, all brushes are stiff. I'm new to this whole thing, but I'm satisfied with it.
  101. This brush will give you such a smooth shave James Bond will be jealous. I got this brush for Valentine's Day to replace an old brush of my grandfather's, and it's awesome. It takes much less soap to use, and you can feel it working, but not in an uncomfortable way. I got a close smooth shave with no knicks or burns, which makes all the difference. The handle is a nice dark wood stain which makes it look much better crafted than the one in the picture. You can SMELL the stain when the brush is wet, hopefully that might go away or be less loud the more I use it. Highly recommended!<br /><br />On a side note, skip the multi blade jazz and get a safety razor or a two blade one. I use a Gilette Atra II razor, and I haven't had a better shave since switching to it and a brush.
  102. What can you say about Tweezerman? Great product, very light-weight and good brush as well. I did notice after about a month that the brush started to give way and had some falling out but nothing major as is expected with just any brush. So far, great product!

  108. [[ASIN:B000G647Y8 Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush]]<br />As you've probably seen in your hunt for a badger hair shave brush, they - for the most part - aren't cheap. Badger hair is prized for the way it wicks up water and as we all know in wet shaving, water is your friend! Then you found this one. I've purchased 2 of these. The first one I bought was $15, then 2 weeks later they dropped the price to $11 so I bought another. Keep an eye on this one, you may get it for an even better price. I am currently using 1 and keeping the other as a back-up. The fact is, this is a really good economical badger hair brush. It's not made with the best badger hair but if it were, it'd be $150.00 instead of $15.00. I'll say this: for beginners and even those with tons of experience but on a budget, you won't be disappointed by this little brush. It holds lots of water and it lathers up soaps really well. It's very soft on the face and gets into all the little places on the face, including by the nostrils and earlobes. For this price, you won't be disappointed with it. Very minimal shedding. I've used it probably 30 times and only had to dig 2 hairs out of my shave soap.

There are better brushes, to be sure, which is why I don't give it 5 stars. Mine loses the occasional hair, but not often. It is not the softest brush out there either, but still better than boar. If you want better than this, you are going to be spending $80 or more. Bottom line: You are getting a above average brush for bottom of the barrel prices.

  118. I've been a wet shaver for over a year now. I started with a cheap synthetic brush and moved on to this as my first natural hair brush. I have been using it daily for three months, and it has not held up well at all.<br /><br />PROS:<br />- Very good performance, helping to build a lot of lather quickly, better than synthetic.<br />- Light weight and nicely balanced.<br /><br />NEUTRAL:<br />- Smell was a little worse than most other animal hair brushes, but shampoo and conditioner and it went away after a week.<br />- Brushes are bristly, which can either help exfoliate skin or feel scratchy depending on your preference.<br /><br />CONS:<br />- Loses several hairs each use, not just during the break-in period of the first few shaves, but even after daily shaving for three months.<br />- Knot was misaligned and overall the brush has a very cheap appearance.<br />- Coating began to bubble, crack, and flake off within a few weeks.<br />- Wood underneath coating dried out and cracked.<br /><br />Check the customer images to see what I'm talking about.<br /><br />The brush does its job well, if a little scratchy. And I could still use it for probably several more months before the knot completely falls apart or the wood itself rots or cracks fully.<br /><br />But I would not recommend spending the money on this item. There are a lot of good boar brushes in the same price range that will outlast and outperform this product, such as the [[ASIN:B003BWNR9A Omega Shaving Brush #10048 Boar Bristle aka The PRO 48]]. Or if you do a little research online, you'll find places that offer quality badger brushes for a little more money that are very good quality.

  123. For the price I paid I couldn't be more pleased with this brush. For only a few bucks more than a synthetic or some other kind of animal hair you can get a badger brush which best for building a good shaving lather. The fist 5 or 6 times I used it I did loose a few hairs but haven't since, also this one like most badger brushes did have a certain musky animal smell to it. I didn't find it over whelming but did try to get rid of it using shampoos and hand soaps, I read online some folks soak it in Borax but I worried it might damage the hairs. After the 6th use or so the smell was gone so I guess just using it more often might be best. I also wanted to get a stand for it so it would drip dry and prevent bacteria but didn't want to spend more on that than I did for the brush so I made one out of a coat hanger. It's ghetto but it works! This brush isn't the biggest but it gets the job done just fine. I wouldn't hesitate to buy another for myself or as a gift!
  124. I have purchased this model and have been using it for more than 2 years now and it has worked wonderfully well. And it would not fit into the safety razor stand. And it took veeeery long for lather to come when compared to the tweezerman shaving brush. So don't think twice, and move to Tweezerman's Shaving Brush if you are committing to a shaving brush and value-for-money is what you are looking for.

Now I have a stand, but what's interesting is that the brush, after nearly two years, has continued to hold up extremely well, even with my slovenly care. Top notch!
  126. Well, I was skeptical that an old-time razor would be something that would be so much better than the newest technology of the day.<br /><br />Well a whole package to do it right and all for under a $100.00 to start with everything. But pry right around $5.00 a month to shave after this month. [...]<br /><br />Shaving Soap not new age creams! I thought they were crazy when first told this but its true. Like being in the old barber shop of Al Capone days of only the top notch artist can perform, almost to the point of a spa for your face! This is as close as you get for personal use.<br />Lots of Soaps, A classic and old product used for years and the original [...]<br />This place is awesome. May not sound all METRO for some of you guys, but trust me on this one. My Mother owns and operates a full service Beauty Salon. I have used all kinds of fancy and expensive products because my whiskers are a tad tougher. The products all Smell Great, Feel Great on the skin, and History reborn.<br /><br />Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush<br />http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000G647Y8/ref=oss_product<br />Brush quality is important but they can get pricy. As much as I love the Edwin Jagger razor, their brushes are not any better quality; more aesthetically pleasing if that is the goal, but also 3-4 times the price for this little gem. The best thing is that its 100% Badger Hair (which is what you want, softer than boar's hair) and it comes with a lifetime guarantee to boot.<br /><br />Tweezerman for Men - Stainless Steel for Ingrown Hair Splintertweeze<br />http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000EMYHA8/ref=oss_product<br />What can I say about the need for this interment of torture? Well it is unfortunately a MANecessity, this baby is colored yellow to find it pretty fast, with the wide discs on each side for a guys little bit bigger hands, also provide a great way to pick it up. Trust me, when you first get jabbed with this thing, you WILL always remember it. Beyond razor sharp, but they do the job well. This is my second pair in my life. First pair was not this fancy; Tweeserman did fix, straighten, and sharpen several times in their life as is free with the lifetime warranty, but they have become must have in the first aid kit out in my shed. There is nothing better for splinters!-4 times the price for this little gem. The best thing is that its 100% Badger Hair (which is what you want, softer than boar's hair) and it comes with a lifetime guarantee to boot.   127. Appearance/build quality: I like to have a classy looking bathroom, so I was disappointed when this brush arrived and it had a noticeable crack in the wooden handle, about half an inch long and stemming from the metal rim of the brush. It also has a noticeable scuff mark on the bottom of the handle. None of this affects it's performance, but for me at least part of the allure of brush/bowl shaving is the nicer look compared to simply using a canned shave cream. The obvious problems with the brush I received does not speak well for the companies quality control either, though. Performance: The brush works well enough, although the bristles are stiffer than I would like and are not softening up as well as I would expect. It is also losing many of them, usually several per shave. At this rate it will not be long before the brush is too thin to provide a good lather. Personally, I don't use this brush anymore and only keep it around for traveling and in case something happens to my primary brush (dropping it in the toilet or something). That said, at it's cheap price point it may be a good option if you are looking for a cheap brush just to test out wet shaving with. Judging from the other reviews here the company's quality varies wildly from one brush to another, so it's a bit of a gamble. Honestly I would really recommend buying something else, even if it is a bit more expensive, but your mileage may vary.
  128. This brush is a great value. It feels great and works well with my [[ASIN:B001JHEY14 Proraso Shaving Soap, Ultra Sensitive Skin 5.2 oz (147 g)]]. The only problem I have had, is that for the first few months it lost hairs constantly. It wasn't a big deal because I just shaved them off of my face, but it was annoying. For the price you can't really beat it though.
  129. I got it for my father after reading the other product reviews. The price was competitive and after Dad used it for the first time....I was glad I made the right choice. He said a night and day difference compared to his earlier synthetic brush he used to use. He is hooked for life!
  130. This brush is a noticeable improvement over the cheap brush I bought at the grocery store. This brush is so much softer and doesn't shed like an old dog. I don't know if it really improves the effectiveness of my shave but it definitely improves the quality of the experience.
  131. This is definitely a massive improvement over my old non-badger shaving brush. Seems to pick up the soap better, and spread it easier. The only problem is that it really, really, really smelled of what I assume is badger. I'd characterize it as being like a wet dog but angrier, though my wife had colostomy bag flashbacks. First time I used it the smell spread out and filled the bathroom pungently. After soaking it in hot water and vinegar then applying copious amounts of baking soda, my wife proclaims herself content with the smell, though it's still there enough that she wouldn't want to sniff the brush directly. Despite that, seems to be a good brush for the price. I'd suspect that mine might be an outlier in terms of smell, but I don't have the experience to say one way or the other.
  132. We have two pairs of Tweezerman tweezer's in our household, and they are very well-crafted. Durable, precise, and comfortable to use. So I took a chance thinking the same attention to detail would carry over to this shaving brush. Alas, that is not the case. First, the brush I received is not the brush pictured. Mine came with a shiny chrome handle (?) -- though upon reading some of the one-star reviews describing the wood cracking after only a short period, maybe that is a blessing. The bristles also started falling out with the first use. And continued with the second. I haven't yet used it a third time. All that said, it is cheap for a shaving brush. For that reason alone, I will not go through the hassle of returning it, and instead will use it until it completely falls apart, then go back to [...]and get a real shaving brush. I am being generous with two stars for the low price.
  133. kind of smaller than imagined
  134. Switching to a DE razor at almost 50 years old, this is my first shaving brush. So far it remains my ONLY shaving brush. So I may not be the best judge as I have nothing to compare it to. I can tell you that it has been in use for approximately 90 shaves and it looks just like it did out of the package. I treat it very well. I do not submerge it in water, I rinse it well, and I hang it bristles down to dry. It lost a few hairs early on and only an occasional one since.<br /><br />The only caveat I would offer is that this brush is very soft. I have always used Taylor or Old Bond Street shaving creams. They are very moist and very soft. They do not require any force to lather, only movement. I'm guessing that if you use a shaving soap that requires a fair amount of pressure to lather, it may be difficult, or at the very least you may see a great deal more wear and tear on the brush than I have seen. I don't know how well it would hold up.<br /><br />But then again, as I said, I don't have any experience with others for comparison. I know I'm happy enough with my own experience to have just ordered another for a spare. At this price (you can spend outrageous amounts of money on a brush) you can't go wrong.
  135. Have been using this brush for over a year now and no bristle loss, works great. Couldn't even see paying more for one. Just make sure you hang it to dry it.
  136. I picked up this brush to replace a synthetic one I tried. This brush produces the best foam. It is even better than the brush that got me started from 'Art of shaving'
  137. Some of the bristles come out over time. Upon vigorous use, I have seen as many as three bristles come out. I think the Tweezerman shaving brush is great value. Buying a $100 silver trip badger hair brush is excessive. Start with this one. It does the job well.<br />Also, I take good care of it. That means soaking it first before shaving, squeezing out the cream after you're done shaving, rinsing well, squeezing out the water, shaking (or flicking) out most of the water, then *most importantly* hanging it bristles down. Do this and it'll be a great shaving brush that doesn't break the bank!
  138. I got this to replace my horse hair brush. Atleast I think it was horse hair. Definitely not badger hair. The Tweezerman brush only cost me $13 so I thought it would be a good place to start with the badger hair brushes which can get quite expensive. The first couple of times of use it lost some hairs but not alot and that seemed to cease. The horse hair brush I had was much softer but didn't make a lather with the soap like this one does. This brush creates a nice thick lather with shaving soap, seems fairly well made and dosen't look too cheap so if you're just getting into using a brush and soap for shaving the Tweezerman badger hair brush isn't a bad place to start.
  139. Husband loves this brush as it harkens back to the olden days when men used these for applying shaving cream.
  140. Forget getting those brush's at the big box stores. Tweezerman is the real deal. Parts of the brush do not come out as you use it. It's great.
  141. I used a Tweezerman brush for about 7 years and loved it. It became so soft that it didn't make good shaving foam and so I ordered a new one. (Note that after all that use - it still had a full set of bristles and looked new - great quality.) The new one appears to be the same as my old one in style and manufacture, but has about 1/3 less bristles and they are so hard and sharp that I don't enjoy using it. A big disappointment from my first experience with Tweezerman brushes. I wish they gave comparison information about the bulk of bristles and the stiffness of them so I can buy with confidence without getting to feel the product in person. I assume there are different levels of quality and I would pay a little more for a higher quality product but do not feel the need for the $150 versions I also see offered by other sellers.
  142. I hate this brush so much it's not even funny. It loses hairs every time, and it simply isn't worth buying the same item again to risk getting another bad one. Just buy a better quality one, and stay away from this one.
  143. You get what you pay for. If i had to do it all over again i would have spent a few more shekels on a higher quality product. Yes, it does the job but i am constantly picking out hairs from my soap, razor and face. Very annoying. I can only imagine this brush lasting 2 months at most with the amount of hair it loses.   144. This brush is really hard to beat - especially for the price. I have other `high end' English badger brushes - most costing 5-7X more than this one - that have been relegated to the bench since I got the Tweezerman. The bristles have a better stiffness to them, and as a result I find that they generate a richer lather and raise my whiskers more effectively. The one minor caution about this brush is that when I received it and began using it, it did give off a fairly heinous odor. Smelled, I suppose, like a wet badger! But fear not, the odor does dissipate with use. I have a small jar of Barbicide (the blue disinfecting liquid you see at the barbershop) that I use for my straight razors - I dunked the bristles in there for about 10 minutes after the initial use and then gave it a thorough rinse. That's really not a necessary step I'm sure, but it did seem to help eliminate the odor a bit faster. I've also used it primarily with scented soaps - in particular Tabac, Proraso and Classic Shaving Menthol - and that also seemed to get the odor neutralized after 5-10 uses. All in all, this is a really good quality brush at a great price - highly recommended.
  145. This badger brush was my start into wet shaving with a Merkur Safety Razor. I was interested in improving the shaving experience. This brush has raised the level of comfort unbelievably. It lathers the soap very easily and with minimal effort. If you're thinking about abandoning the disposable razors or the expensive blades, use this brush as your starter to try out the safety razor shaving experience.
  146. This is an excellent shaving brush, and the price makes it all that much better. You will find that Badge Hair brushes really are superior, and to find one this inexpensive is a bonus. Good Shaving, Go Straight.

Remember, when storing this item, don't store it on it's base, or the brush will lose proper form. Store it on it's side or in a hanging shaving brush stand like this one http://www.amazon.com/Omega-172-Chrome-Shaving-Brush/dp/B000K7ESII/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1320932515&sr=8-1

  156. I bought this brush for my father for Christmas.   157. I have been using this brush for about 3 months. Be sure to break in your brush. Prior to regular use, in order to help remove loose hairs, you must break in your new brush. This can be done by washing it with soap and water and gently swiping it in a circular motion, back and forth, in the palm of your hand. I still loose a few hairs every use. The wood handle will eventually crack due to water damage, unless you let your brush dry by hanging it by the wood handle, hairs downward. I love DE shaving and will never go back to disposable razers. I use a [[ASIN:B000NL0T1G Merkur Model 180 Long Handled Safety Razor]] with feather and derby blades.
  158. Although I ordered the Tweezerman brush shown, I received a chrome-handled \\"Simply Beautiful\\" brush. It seems to be essentially the same item and I have no complaints, but it's not what I ordered. I do have to admit that, for the price, this is a pretty nice brush. The quality of the badger hair is good enough for a beginner like me and it absorbs more than enough water. So far, I haven't lost a single bristle and it whips up a nice, thick lather. Although I have nothing to compare it to, the bristles seem a bit \\"prickly\\" which is probably due to the lower quality badger hair one gets for the price. There's little doubt that I will be upgrading to a higher quality brush when this one starts to wear out but, for now, I'm enjoying this one. Maybe whoever picked the item from stock made a mistake, or maybe these brushes are interchangeable. In any case, when you receive your order, check it carefully. For whatever it's worth, I decided to use it rather than return it and have no regrets.

He's used the brush for only a week though so that is only a guess. The brush is also made from badger hair which from my research before buying this product is the best material for a shaving brush. All of our research from youtube indicates that ridding oneself of razor bumps starts primarily with the preparation of your face before shaving.   166. For the same price you can choose one of several Franks Shaving Badger Brushes, Omega Boar Brushes or The Body Shop Synthetic brush. I accidentally ordered two of these and the knot fell out of the handle of the first after a month and both leave badger hair in my soap and on my face. Also, if you read reviews outside of Amazon you'll see that my experience isn't abnormal. It would appear that wet shaving newcomers with nothing to compare it to are responsible for the good reviews Tweezerman has. However once you've experienced a good quality brush the Tweezerman won't be acceptable. TLDR: Why buy something you'll likely replace, just buy a good one once and be done.

  168. Somehow Tweezerman markets a credible badger-hair brush for a fraction of what you'd expect, considering the price of the high-end models out there. Building lather quickly and well is a lot easier with badger. A drug-store brush is normally made of horse-hair and those don't build a good lather. For brushes, I've owned a horse-hair, a Tweezerman, and a badger silvertip that costs 8 times what the Tweezerman does. On a 1 to 10 scale I'd rate a horse-hair brush as a 1, the Tweezerman a 7 and the hoity-toytie silvertip a 10.

  182. I have shaved with a boar bristle brush for years and was happy. But when the last brush died (fell on ther floor and the handle shattered) I decided to upgrade to this Tweezerman brush.<br /><br />Before buying it, I visited several web sites on the care of badger bristle brushes. When mine arrived I gave it a gentle wash with shampoo and conditioner. Then I combed it through with the widest tooth comb my wife has. Only a few hairs detached.<br /><br />After each time using it, I let warm water run over the bristles (pointing down), and then flick off excess water.<br /><br />I have seen NO further loss or detachment of bristles.<br /><br />And YES, there is a difference between shaving with a boar bristle and a badger bristle brush.
  183. loved the brush for the first month i had it, then it fell apart. the brush fibers came unglued from the handle.
  184. this brush is twice as effective as the cheap boars hair brushes. I was impressed how quickly it lathered. It's soft and no hair fell out in first 15 uses.
  185. For the price this is a great brush, yes it does shed, but it lathers nicely and is a lot softer than a boar brush. For the price what do you expect though, it is a great introductory brush for someone who isn't sure if they are going to even like using a brush and probably won't want to spend 2-10x as much on a higher end one. I gave it five stars for a brush at this price point not as a comparison across the board for shaving brushes. Obviously it will be much different that a $200 handmade brush, but who is going to want to make that investment if they don't even know if they are going to want to use it in a week.<br /><br />This brush works great, does what it is supposed to and is a great alternative to boar or horse hair in the price range. (although I know some shavers really like the boar and horse) If the shedding is going to be an issue, then just spend the money and get a higher end brush.<br /><br />Update: While yes the brush did lose some hair when I first used it(first 2-3 shaves), after the initial loss I find that it is no longer regularly shedding, I noticed a hair or two hairs every few uses. I am now using [[ASIN:B0040QJ34O Kent BLK8 Traditional Large Pure Silver Tip Badger Gents Shaving Brush]], which is much different than the above mentioned brush, but as previously stated it is almost 20x the cost. I still use my tweezerman in my travel bag and have no issues it is a good brush.

  188. My husband recently got into \\"old school\\" shaving -- safety razor, soap in a mug, the whole nine yards. I originally got him a different brush elsewhere that was made of synthetic bristles and did the job OK, but not what he was expecting. Got him the Tweezerman, which is made with boars hair, and it made a load of difference. He absolutely loves it. Considering most boars hair brushes are upwards of $50 or more, this is an AMAZING bargain
  189. My first brush and I cannot recommend it. It builds a good lather, but won't release soap to your face. The more I used the brush the more lather it REMOVED from my face. Thoroughly disappointed! And as a previous reviewer noted... yes it stinks!
  190. When discussing shave brushes there are many aspects to consider.<br /><br />First of all...Badger/Boar/Synthetic?<br /><br />Price?<br /><br />Size?<br /><br />Many variables. I'll break down what I like, and why, and hopefully that will allow you to better understand what I mean.<br /><br />I do not shave only my face, but my entire head. I have a goatee, and eyebrows...but everything else is baby's butt smooth as much of the time as possible.<br /><br />This means that I would prefer a brush that holds more soap than this one, and also one with a large cluster of hairs to cover more area in one swipe. Also a deeper bristled brush would allow for more soap to stay buried inside, making building more lather on the face easier to achieve.<br /><br />Compared to a similarly priced boar brush the tweezerman does feel VERY luxurious against the skin.<br /><br />A cheap boar brush will provide an easier time of whipping lather for inexperienced users.<br /><br />I guess the only real complaint I have about the tweezerman is that it's too small to cover this much surface area quickly. But other than that...great deal. If you also shave your head I might suggest spending a bit more and getting a larger badger brush.
  191. I purchased this in May of '09 and have been pleased with it since the day I got it. I wanted to try straight razor shaving at that time, and didn't want to spend a fortune on something that I may not like. I also knew that I wanted a badger hair brush, and that good ones tended to be expensive. This Tweezerman brush is an exception to that rule. The quality is very high, and the price was well worth it. Of course, I'm still straight razor shaving with this brush and enjoying my morning shave. This is a good brush for starting wet shaving on a budget, but it's also just a good brush overall.<br /><br />I would note that like other reviewers my brush lost some bristles at first. This was maybe ten or twenty in the first two weeks. It continued to lose a few every shave for a while, and then it stopped.<br /><br />I also would point out that I do NOT mash the brush down when working up a lather, and that I do so on my face rather than in the cup. Some have noted that this can be hard on your brush (any brush,) but I think that is because of a tendency by some men to mash the brush against their face when doing so. I also shake my brush out pretty thoroughly before hanging it to dry.<br /><br />Finally, if you are planning to try straight razor (or safety razor) shaving for the first time you need to buy quality items with basic features. E.g. this Tweezerman shaving brush. You will probably spend about $125.00-$150.00 to do it right but economically. Ongoing expenses include periodic sharpening, styptic pencil, and shave soap. Of course, I've saved more than my initial investment since switching. I also get a better, and more pleasant shave.
  192. I have been a classic shaver (DE) for several years now and own a fair share of related products including some \\"high-end\\" badger brushes. I had been thinking of adding a Tweezerman to the collection and finally ordered.<br /><br />It comes packaged in a flimsy plastic pack but that is the only 'cheap' thing about this brush. I did not notice any funky animal odor upon my initial inspection nor did the brush smell bad when soaked. I ran it through my usual new-brush cleaning routine of a dish-water liquid palm lather followed by a 20 minute soak in a 1/6 part vinegar-water mix. I then left the brush to dry over-night. The Tweezerman knot bloomed beautifully when dry and very soft to the touch.<br /><br />For the first shave, I paired it with the \\"Taylor of Bond Street Sandalwood\\" cream. I left the brush to soak in my shave bowl for 15 minutes, shook it gently a couple of times to get rid of the excess water and proceeded to whip up the cream. It created excellent lather in seconds. The feel on the face is very slightly scritchy, the badger hair used are surprisingly soft and of very good quality. After the shave, I gently towel-dried it, then hung it upside down to dry which is important for the longevity of any shave brush.<br /><br />I honestly couldn't discern any substantial difference between this and my comparatively expensive Edwin Jagger best badger. In fact, I found the Tweezerman to have a bit more of a back bone for better and easier lather. For the price, Tweezerman badger brush offers great value and performance. Very highly recommended.
  193. I didnt expect much from such a cheap brush, but it still managed to let me down. Not only did it give off a horrible chemical smell, but whatever they polish/varnish the handle with dripped off immediately after my first use, leaving my white counter a dirty muddy shade.
  194. My husband absolutely raves about this brush. He says it is the best for lathering he's ever used and he wouldn't want to go back to any other kind of brush. It was a hit!
  195. This brush is easily on par with many badger hair brushes costing four times as much.<br /><br />I BELIEVE I KNOW WHY OTHERS WERE HAVING PROBLEMS WITH THIS BRUSH ...<br /><br />I read some of the previous reviews regarding excessive bristle loss, cracked handles, and the knot coming out of the handle. ALL of these problems are symptoms of improper care and use! I'm willing to wager that this is the first shaving brush for most purchasers, who are attracted by its inexpensive price. So, here are some care and maintenance rules for shaving brushes:<br /><br />Although a shaving brush has a flat handle, this is so it can be set down conveniently while shaving. It should NEVER be allowed to dry sitting on its handle. It is absolutely crucial that you rinse the brush after use and then HANG IT WITH THE HANDLE UP (BRISTLES DOWN) in order to dry. Failure to do so will result in an early demise of your brush -- cracked wood handle, rotting bristles, loosening of the knot, etc. You can make a holder out of wire or a coat hanger if you do not want to buy one.<br /><br />Also, when whipping up lather, your finger tips should be grasping the base of the bristles where they meet the handle, with the flat of the handle against your palm. Whip the lather using only the TIPS of the bristles. You don't want to \\"squash\\" the bristles while whipping up the lather.<br /><br />Finally, when you rinse the brush, hold it bristles up under a gentle stream of water. Then, hold it with the bristles down and wring the bristles by gently squeezing the bristles between your fingers and thumb. Now, holding the brush where the bristles and handle meet between your forefinger and thumb, GENTLY shake the brush two or three times. Vigorous shaking holding only the handle will damage the brush. Now hang the brush with the handle up to dry.<br /><br />Follow these rules -- which are standard for any brush -- and you should enjoy years of shaves from your Tweezermans brush!<br /><br />[UPDATE #1: I wrote the above after two months of use. This update, after ONE YEAR of use, convinces me even more that this was one of the best shaving buys ever. It continues to perform perfectly, is well broken in, and is NOT losing bristles! I have recommended this brush to many friends, and all have been very happy with their purchase. Follow the care instructions above, and I believe you will be very happy with this brush!]<br /><br />[UPDATE #2: 2 years, 8 months later and still going strong! Although I have two other brushes (mostly for travel) this brush is still my \\"go to\\" and on average gets used 5 to 6 days a week. I still stand by my review above. This is without a doubt one of the best values for the money.]<br /><br />[UPDATE #3: 4 years, 4 months, still going strong. Still getting used 5 to 6 times a week. BTW, when I shave, usually at a minimum I do a \\"two-pass\\" shave (with grain, against grain). So for every shave, I lather up at least twice. On Sundays and days with important meetings, I do a 3-pass shave (against-, with-, & across-the-grain).]rote the above after two months of use. This update, after ONE YEAR of use, convinces me even more that this was one of the best shaving buys ever. It continues to perform perfectly, is well broken in, and is NOT losing bristles! I have recommended this brush to many friends, and all have been very happy with their purchase. Follow the care instructions above, and I believe you will be very happy with this brush!]<br /><br />[UPDATE #2: 2 years, 8 months later and still going strong! Although I have two other brushes (mostly for travel) this brush is still my \\"go to\\" and on average gets used 5 to 6 days a week. I still stand by my review above. This is without a doubt one of the best values for the money.]<br /><br />[UPDATE #3: 4 years, 4 months, still going strong. Still getting used 5 to 6 times a week. BTW, when I shave, usually at a minimum I do a \\"two-pass\\" shave (with grain, against grain). So for every shave, I lather up at least twice. On Sundays and days with important meetings, I do a 3-pass shave (against-, with-, & across-the-grain).]

As i understand a Pure brush is put together and then cut to shape, the result is that at least for the first use the bristles felt a little sharp, or harsh on my face. which I expect will improve with time as I use the brush.   212. I read the reviews about this brush and was hesitant to buy it because it's so cheap. Several of the other reviews talked about how it loses hair. I saw a few reply to those saying that if you take proper care of it then it won't. Well, I assure you it still does. It started losing hair the first time I used it and has continued several shaves later. I won't be buying this again. I guess you really do get what you pay for.
  213. I began D.E. shaving about 2 months ago. Like many I bought this brush since it was inexpensive and I needed everything to get started. The brush works like a champ, doing everything I needed it to do. Mixing creams in a bowl is my technique for lather. I hear a lot of complaints about this brush losing hairs, the knot coming out of the handle, etc. The trick to help prevent this is to make sure that after soaking the brush (never have the water level into the knot) is to flick the excess water out by holding the bristles with the thumb and index finger. This will help prevent losing the bristles from the handle due to excessive force. Also make sure to hang the brush on a stand so that water will not drain back into the handle and it can properly dry. This will ensure that the glue holding the bristles will not break down. After a couple of weeks soak the brush in dishwashing soap and swirl it around to remove residue. I have since added an Omega boar brush to my small collection, but the Tweezerman badger is still in the rotation. For me, this was a good first purchase in a brush. As with all brushes, will give great service if properly cared for.
  214. I have had this for two weeks and it seems to be fine. I don't see any bristles coming out. My only complaint is that it is really short and with my big hands I have trouble working it in a regular sized shaving mug. Of course I have bear paws so this may only be my problem. For the money though I will use it up!
  215. The brush is not the most comfortable I've used; but I lived with it. Then it broke up. The bristles detached from the handle all at once. This is a poor quality product. My previous brush lasted 20 years! This one lasted a few months.

  225. When I received the brush, there was a little knocking sound, which I figured was just due to it being a relatively cheap brush. The next day, I soaked the brush for a few minutes in a little bit of water, shook it out, and hung it up to dry (bristles pointing down). Then the next day, I did another soak for a few minutes and shook out the extra water before building up some lather on my face. While applying more shaving cream for my second pass (and using the correct grip), the handle separated from the bristles. The bristles did not separate from the glue; The glue actually broke - half was on the bristles and half in the handle. So, clearly there was a reason for the knocking sound I heard when I unboxed the brush... it was already broken (or darn close to broken) when I got it. On the plus side, the brush builds better lather quicker than my cheapy boar brush.<br /><br />UPDATE: Upon further inspection, it turns out there was an air bubble in the glue that secured the knot in the handle. I was able to fix my brush by roughing up the surfaces involved and applying some Devcon epoxy. I've been using the repaired brush 2 or 3 times a week for 5 months without any more problems. The brush is definitely worth the price, especially for beginners. It works up quite a good lather for me but, as with all wet shaving tools, your mileage may vary.

They probably got the hair for mine from the area next to badger social glands...<br /><br />phew...<br />after a lot of rinsing (with shampoo, dish soap, vinegar in water and more dish soap) i got it to something i would consider putting against my face.<br />the good news is that after a few shaves most of the smell is gone.   246. I've been shaving since I was 12 years old and have tried every combination of razor, cream and gel you can imagine. About 4 years ago I had a good old fashioned barber shop shave and was floored by how comfortable the shave was. I had never been able to duplicate it. I have a great deal of Scandinavian blood in me so my beard grows fast, thick and curly. I read that using a brush will help make the hair stand up properly for a better shave. The brush arrived yesterday and it is a very beautiful piece for sure. The brush really did make a difference, I have never had this close of a shave at home before and I had no razor bumps or burns afterwards. If you have a curly beard or a stubborn beard, this will help you get that close shave you've been looking for.
  247. It seems a little light and moderate build quality, but it works fine and I've only lost a few hairs now and then. I make sure to rinse it thoroughly and let it dry with the bristles down and I'm confident it will last for awhile. Overall, I like it and don't regret buying it - especially at the price!
  248. The brush I received had a terrible case of \\"badger smell\\". After weeks of trying to get the smell out with alternating soaks of vinegar and soap it still stinks. Initially it stunk up the entire open area of the apartment, and I had to cover and close the brush into a cupboard. It was bad enough I felt the need to write my first review. Unlucky, I suppose, but I feel from now on I would only buy brushes from local retailers now where I have the option of returning a potentially stinky brush with less hassle than mailing it (even if I spend a multiple more for the product). It seems there are plenty of people that are happy with the brushes they received and for between 10-20$, this product offers great value at that price point. I simply didn't have that experience. For the product's sake, I did test it a few times. Brushes do a great lathering job, and it does that. It lost a few hairs initially, but seems solid after a few uses. *Note: my experience has everything to do with the product I have experience with, and nothing to do with any of the distributors supplying the product. **Note: Before purchasing, I wasn't aware that some brushes have these odors. Give it a search for yourself. The recommended remedy is soaking the brush in a solution of water and vinegar, soap, or borax and for most people the problem is solved within a week.
  249. Purchased this shaving brush a couple months ago. After its initial shedding period the brush has lost very few bristles. The bristles are firm and give a good lather. I use a brush stand that points the bristles down when drying to keep the bristle glue from loosening.
  250. This is my first badger brush. First of all? What the h@#$ is that smell? Badger crotch-rot? Are these, by chance, the hairs from the area closest to the badger's anal glands (look it up - this odor is vile)? Somebody here suggested a (singular) shampooing and conditioning. HA! Try witch hazel, soaps, bleach, acetone, oxy clean and vinegar (I didn't try gasoline, tolulene, B-12 chemtrol or Seafoam or Tears of Chuck Norris)! Holy crap. What is that odor? Nevertheless, I like the performance of the brush. After about 3 weeks, the bristles have softened up nicely. I will be getting another brush (can we say \\"upgrading?\\").
  251. My only surprise (I won't even call it a complaint) was that when I first used it - the animal smell became VERY pronounced. I had to wonder how many badgers lost their pubic hairs to make this brush! But the smell soon subsided after another use or two. Now it smells like soap and awesomeness. The feel is wonderful as is its ability to produce a lather. I'm an artist so taking care of a brush is already second nature - I keep it dry and clean in-between shaves and I only lose a hair or two when I use it. Very happy early on, we'll see how it lasts during the long haul.
  252. For what you pay for this badger brush, you cant go wrong. Of course there are more expensive and better quality brushes out there but this one isnt a slouch by any stretch of the imagination. Good badger brush that lathers extremely well. You may lose a couple hairs initially here and there but no biggie. Also mine didnt have a bad smell at all. After reading the numerous reviews i smelled the brush as soon as i got it to see what the fuss was about. While it does have a distinct smell it is nothing that is overpowering or unbearable, and it goes away with use. Bottom line if want a good badger brush this is a solid choice that wont break the bank. Great starter or daily use brush.
  253. I bought this as a travel brush for my trip to England so I wouldn't risk losing my expensive badger brush. I used it a total of 4 times. 3 times before I left to break it in and 1 time at the hotel. The entire knot fell out in my hand during the fourth shave. Extremely irritated and disappointed. I didn't expect the best brush ever but I expected to get more then 4 shaves out of it.
  254. The Tweezerman Shave brush is brush that Works well for 'Face-Lathering'. It does not hold enough lather or water to bowl lather for me. Very prickly at first then eventually breaks in and softens up. Just remember, this brush is Small. Smaller than you think it is. If you're beginning, you can buy this brush, I wouldn't bash you for it, but Please spend a couple extra bucks and buy a Vulfix Super Badger brush, I would take ONE Vulfix over a free lifetime of Tweezermans (and believe me, you would to!)
  255. This brush is a great value. It's one of the least expensive badger-hair brushes you'll find, and it will perform just as well as any of them. If you're looking for your first shave brush, save yourself the disappointment of boar-hair and start with this brush. The handle is a simple natural wood handle, with the unfortunately conspicuous TWEEZERMAN branding. If you ever upgrade to a higher-end brush, you'll be happy to keep this around in your dopp kit for travel.
  256. Bought minds over a year ago and its still going strong. Gives a good lather and the price is great!
  257. I am just beginning the process of wet shaving using non-cartridge razors and brushes. I bought a NOS shaving kit at an antique store, which had a mug, soap, and a boar brush. That led to me buying this at the local grocery store for $15, and so far so good. Much better than the boar brush, it does loose hairs but I figured that was normal. I can't compare it to anything other than my old boar brush and I'd rate this as a MUCH better brush at making a good lather. For $15 I don't think you can go wrong.
  258. have used this brush about ten times since delivery. the softness and fullness of this style is great. I you want to enjoy the small pleasure of being a man while shaving, get this brush!
  259. I just started using shaving soaps and a straight razor a few weeks ago. I purchased this brushed based on the reviews. I wasn't sure how much to spend so after researching carefully I chose this one. I realize the more expensive ones may be better, however I asked myself these questions when deciding on a brush. When you have shaved in the past what has made you more prone to irritation-<br /><br />1. The Shaving cream/ soap you are using?<br />2- The razor you are using?<br />3- The method in which you apply your shaving cream/soap?<br /><br />I would conclude razors and cream/ gels are the bigger irritants. For this reason I didn't see the brush making that much of a difference in the shaving process. I chose to put a little more money into the soap and the razor itself. I am sure the cheap ones are not great but for the price I am happy with this one that is more middle of the road.
  260. Good starter badger brush, some hair fell out on the first use but now it seems to be fine. Definitely recommended for a first badger brush.
  261. This is a great brush at a great price! I am relatively new to the world of straight blades (about a year or so), but I do know that this is MUCH better than my boar brush.
  262. I've been using the Tweezerman for over a year now. I have four other brushes to compare it with. On the positive side, it is inexpensive, the bristles dry relatively quickly (nice travel brush), and has stiff bristles that make it easy to lather soaps and creams. On the negative side, the tips are fairly scratchy, the loft is not uniform in shape, it continues to shed bristles, and worst-of-all the wet bristles stink to this day.
  263. But they really do. I had a boar's hair brush before this, and the badger bristles really are far superior. It takes a lot less soap to make a good lather with the badger. If you're a brush user, definitely give it a try.
  264. This is a pretty good price for a brush, but I wouldn't recommend it. The bristles did not feel so great on my face, they were actually fairly painful rubbing on my face. The brush must have lost about 10 bristles the first time I used it. While this one is on its way back to amazon I may try another.
  265. This is the best badger brush for the money. Period. Feels good on my face, works up a good lather, dries well, and beats the crap out of my old boar hair brush. My only qualm is that it smells kind of badgery, but it's really not a big deal.
  266. Being a fan of Tweezerman products, I did not think I'd find any problems with this shaving brush as others had. I currently use a boar hair shaving brush that has seen better days. I didn't want to invest too much money into a badger brush and thought this was a good option. I was displeased to find that this was not worth the wait....which was a loooong wait by the way. The first thing I noticed was just how light it was, like it was made of balsa wood. Weight really shouldn't matter because it's just a brush I'm sticking in soap and rubbing on my face once a day but I must say, it felt really cheap. And like others, mine had a lot of hairs come out. Others have complained about the smell and mine smelled too but not to the extent that I wouldn't use it. I mean really, it comes from an animal. My boar brush smelled as well which quickly left as I'm sure it would on this if I were to keep it. On closer inspection, this cheap wood is split at the top where it meets the bristles which is what prompted me to return it. For around 16 dollars I was willing to put up with hairs falling out and an initial smell, but a crack in the handle is a deal killer. I can see in the future that moisture being allowed into the wood causing it to expand and then contract would render it completely useless when the entire knot loosens from the handle. I suppose with a little creative engineering, I could plug the crack but in this day and age, I'm tired of spending money on products that are sub-par. Based on other reviews, I think this particular shaving brush is a hit or miss. Unfortunately mine was a miss. I do appreciate the hassle free return policy and I will be using it.
  267. This brush worked well for the first three years but is now loosing a few hairs every time I shave and NO I don't store it bristles up. I store this blade in an old ceramic shaving mug with a side spout for holding brushes.<br /><br />I'm now going back to using my 1992 purchased heavy (sterling silver handled) silver hair badger brush just as a change of pace. FYI avoid metal handle brushes as they are a pain to keep clean & POLISHED (their handles).<br /><br />ATTN NEWBIES: If your just starting DE shaving this brush will do you right.<br /><br />Four out of Five stars... A good silvertip badger hair brush rates 5+ stars IMO.
  268. I just started wet shaving with brushes and lathers. I started off with a boar's hair brush because it was really cheap. But it didn't produce much lather with the Proraso i had bought. This badger hair brush is way better. Holds water better. Produces way more lather. Dries well. I did notice that it did have a smell. Not too powerful though. I'm sure it'll go away after a few shaves and washes. My first shave about 6 hairs fell out. I hope this isn't going to be a problem though. I'm really hoping this brush lasts.
  269. Tweezerman is a perfect brush for the starting shaver. I'll certainly be moving up to a higher-quality model as I become more experienced with \\"real\\" shaving (using a safety razor and actual blades), but I'm quite satisfied for now. I started out practicing my lathering technique using a modern disposable razor and a shaving soap, to get a good feel for the Tweezerman.<br /><br />Pros:<br />-CHEAP! Tweezerman is about the cheapest brush you can get, while still getting quality.<br />-Badger Hair. Most brushes at this price level are boar hair, which is stiffer and sometimes prickly. Badger hair is a little softer, more luxurious.<br />-Good knot. This is a fairly small brush, but it blossoms into a good shape that does the job well. I have massive hands, and the small handle still works perfectly for me.<br />-I think the smaller size is the key to the price- this is a \\"lite\\" version of a higher-quality product. It's still sized to work well, but there's extra bang for your buck.<br /><br />Cons:<br />-Slightly rough. My wife felt the tip, and being used to feminine-soft makeup brushes, she was not impressed by the Tweezerman. I'd call this brush \\"medium-soft\\", and I'd prefer soft.<br />-Sheds. Top-quality, carefully tended brushes are handed down from father to son. The Tweezerman is not one of those brushes. Even in my first use, I had to fish a couple of hairs out of the lather.<br />-So-so build quality. The top coat of lacquer on the handle had dripped in one spot. There's a pea-sized knob on the handle, and I had to pull a little bit of goop out of the hair. There's no issue in using the product, but it's another small area where you feel the price.<br /><br />Overall, this is the perfect brush for a beginner. It's cheap, but it has the feel of a brush worth at least twice the price. I'd almost list the shedding as a bonus- by the time this brush gives out, it'll probably be the perfect time to finally decide if you're going to stick with it and spend money on a high-end brush. I recommend the Tweezerman highly for beginners, and for anyone who might be looking for an occasional brush to try out in their lineup.<br /><br />Edit: With some actual usage under my belt, this brush holds up very well. I still lose a hair on occasion, but it's not a big annoyance and it's clear the brush will hold up to years of use. I've also tried a cheaper boar brush from Burma, and the difference is immense. The lather I can accomplish working for five minutes with the Burma, I can work up in thirty seconds with my Tweezerman. I'll even admit that I was a bit wrong on the softness- I'd like a bit more stiffness for scrubbing my face, but the tweezerman holds lather so well that I wouldn't risk going much more firm without assurances.for beginners, and for anyone who might be looking for an occasional brush to try out in their lineup. Edit: With some actual usage under my belt, this brush holds up very well. I still lose a hair on occasion, but it's not a big annoyance and it's clear the brush will hold up to years of use. I've also tried a cheaper boar brush from Burma, and the difference is immense. The lather I can accomplish working for five minutes with the Burma, I can work up in thirty seconds with my Tweezerman. I'll even admit that I was a bit wrong on the softness- I'd like a bit more stiffness for scrubbing my face, but the tweezerman holds lather so well that I wouldn't risk going much more firm without assurances.
