Unfortunately, after about a year of light use (it was my travel brush, not my everyday brush), the brush head popped out of the handle. There was no way to re-attach and, eventually, I had to throw it out. I may have been unlucky with my particular brush, but the price did seem too good to be true. My daily use brush (Art of Shaving) was much more expensive and has held up to daily use without any problems. I would recommend spending more to get a higher quality brush.

  276. This is a great starter brush or for someone who wants a quality shaving brush for a great price. I started using this along with the Proraso shaving soap about a week before I received my DE Safety Razor. Whether you decide to switch to the traditional double edge safety razor or stick with a cartridge razor, I would recommend start using shaving soap and a brush. The brush and soap as opposed to the canned shaving cream makes shaving a much more enjoyable experience and also leaves you with healthier cleaner skin.
  277. It has been about 3 weeks of using this product, and I am still losing about 5 hairs each shave. It has become much, much softer, but I don't know about the shedding- leaves me a little suspect as to the quality of the knot. I have read many reviews on this brush, and some shedding within the first short while is normal, however, this extended period of shedding isn't right...might be just me.<br /><br />The brush was really stinky when it came, however, a cleaning protocol- hot water with Dawn soak for an hour, hot water rinses (30 min each) x3, hot water with vinegar x 30 min, and then 2 iterations of 8 hours sitting in lather worked like a charm. No smell any more (other than Proraso!)
  278. I'm by far happier with this brush than with my previous one. Minimal shedding and applies a nice thick lather. After some light shedding following my first few uses I rarely lose any bristles now. An excellent brush, especially for the price.

  289. I'd still be using this only a maid in a hotel evidently decided her husband or her legs would be better off using it than I would. Good thing the brush was inexpensive. It whips up a good head of soap and doesn't get too bogged down or stiff with soap residue nor does it shed much after a day or so. The handle itself fits well in your hand and has decent weight. Given the rather ridiculous price of many other brushes, this one is great. If you're not out to make a fashion statement to your mirror or your spouse I'd say it's the one to get. Update- the bristles all fell out, really? However I got some epoxy at the hardware store, evidently something Tweezerman should have used and put it back together.

I was all into shaving the old way, but I soon realized that using a good gel shave cream and my hand, is the best way to go. To get the best shave ever, shave with the grain with the gel, then go back and shave with some shave secret in the other direction. I love shaving with a double edge blade, but I tried the soap and brush, and it is not for me. I get a closer shave without it, and less irritation.

  296. ... what more could you ask for. I'm definitely not an expert, this is the one and only shaving brush I've ever used, so I can't really compare it to others, but hey, it works! April 2015 Update Still going strong almost 5yrs later! Yes, It now has lost a hair or two, but then again, so have I!
  297. This brush is a good value. I'd recommend it for anyone serious about shaving. The difference between slapping on some canned foam with your hand and lathering up some good shave soap with a badger brush is like night and day. You'll get a much smoother shave whether you're using a safety razor or a disposable. I've used both. The quality of this brush seems to be a step above many others in its price range. Only a couple downsides. First, being new, a badger brush doesn't smell great. I let mine soak and cleaned it up with my shaving soap. Although the brush has a somewhat strong scent it won't transfer to your face, so don't worry ;) After a few shaves the scent dissipates. Also I've been using mine for about a month and it has lost a few stray bristles. Nothing much and it still has a full head of hair on it and I lose maybe one hair a week, shaving once daily. Something to keep in mind, if you get a badger brush you're gonna want some good shave soap & a stand. Although the brush will stand on its handle, it's best to shake it out and hang it upside down to dry better. If I were to eventually upgrade my current shaving set I'd consider a more expensive brush, but I've been very happy with my purchase and would recommend this as an excellent \\"starter brush\\".
  298. Received this brush a few weeks ago as my first foray into DE shaving. This brush is really great for the money. Slight Roadkill scent when first opened, especially wet, but I just cleaned it with shampoo, and in a week, can't even tell it smelled bad. This makes a great lather, and I don't even use a bowl. I just wet my brush, put a pea size amount of Proraso cream on, and lather it up on my face. Some other reviewers complained of shedding hair, but I have not seen any noticeable amount of hair loss from this nice little brush.
  299. This brush was the cheapest badger brush I could find on amazon. And for very good reason it may be badger hair but its extremely uncomfortable and prickly. It holds a small amount of water and cannot create very much lather, probably because it is very loosely packed with hair. I quickly moved on to a brush costing a few times more but it was WELL worth the extra money. Do yourself a favor and skip this brush as a \\"starter\\" and go right for a middle priced brush. Much better brushes including boar brushes can be had for a little more.

  302. This shaving brush is pretty good, but not the best I've owned. It is much more prickly on my skin than the one I replaced.   303. I should have known what I was getting into by spending so little on a brush, but it is my first wet shave brush and I didn't want to make a major investment before I knew I was going to stick with it. On the first shave I removed as much beard hair as brush hairs. After about 6 or 7 uses it still loses about 3 hairs per shave. It does a decent job of working up lather, but I don't expect the brush to last long if it continues at this rate. Thankfully I only paid $11 for it.
  304. On receiving the brush I rinsed it a few times in warm water after gently applying shaving cream foam to the bristles to clean out the manufacturing oils. I had to return the first brush since it started loosing bristles during the first few shaves and bristle loss only got worse during the third and fourth use. I am pleased to note that Amazon responded immediately, the customer representative was effective and I got a replacement brush sent to me. The pros.- pretty cheap compared to the rest of similar brushes in the market. A great starter brush, it lathers soap/shaving cream well, retains water well and the bristles are stiff enough for a good shave. A good starter bush. The cons.- build quality could be better. This brush could be a winner with a large percentage of first time purchaser market if the manufacturers do the 10% needed to address the quality issues. These quality issues make this product a 50-50 instead of a winner. That being said, if you buy and the bristles come out during the first few uses, return it and ask for a replacement and be sure to add your comment to this board so that the manufacturer knows what word-of-mouth and reviews are critically appraising the product quality. Make sure that you tell them to send a product return label for free shipping. You shouldn't have to pay for returning a product that is not performing as promised. When the manufacturers get sufficient numbers back, they will need to reconsider their manufacturing practices. NOTE - A few bristles are coming out of the second brush but no where near the quantity that fell out of the first.
  305. I got this product as a temporary fix for my boyfriend and sadly it was not even that. He said it doesn't hold water like a good wet shaving brush should and the handle is very small. It is only $11 lost, but still kinda sad. Oh well, I tried.
  306. This brush applies my lather very well, although the base of the actual brush feels like it might be too close to the tip, it's tricky to squeeze out the last of that super smooth lather. Other reviews have noted the lack of durability. I've had mine for about a month now, and I only have lost a few bristles, but I can definitely feel how it may fall apart sooner rather than later. But then again, for this price, that's not a surprise. The brush is definitely not the best, but it's MUCH better than the synthetics, and it's much cheaper than almost all other badger hair brushes. If you have the money, go for a best badger hair brush, but if you don't, don't waste your time with synthetics, get this one. You may have to replace it in a few months, but still is a great starter brush.
  307. Does a very goo job. Holds the shaving soap well and dried easily. There are more expensive brushes but I can't imagine them working any better.
  308. Great brush for practically nothing! Holds water well and makes a good lather. It's no silver tip badger brush but I'll stick with plain ol' badger hair for cheap cheap cheap.
  309. For the price I'm happy with the brush. It does shed hairs initially, but the shedding slows down after several uses. I don't recommend it for face lathering, it's a bit too stiff for that, but it bowl lathers very nicely, and I've had no real issues to complain about. Overall all a good beginner brush for those looking to get into wetshaving.
  310. Received this shaving brush as a Christmas gift, i.as very pleased by the quality. the hairs form a very dense brush, that is firm yet soft to the touch. did not lose a bunch of stray hairs after using, like cheaper brushes tend to,.
  311. Badger is best, and this is stiff enough to work well for soaps and soft enough to know it's badger. The wet hair smell goes away quick with use, and stopped shedding hair after about 2 weeks. Not a large diameter brush, but then for the price... After use I wash it, then shake excess water out, then buff the hair against the back of my other hand to help dry (which helps it fluff a little) then I hang to dry. I've been using it as a travel brush since I bought a best badger for daily use, but this is better for soap as it's a little stiffer. Hands down great brush and much better value then the boar brushes available in the pharmacies around the country.
  312. I was so excited about this product - I got this, my new shaving soap, and my nice razor together and proceeded to mix up the lather for the first time ever, and the bundle of hairs popped off in the middle of my shave. It worked really well while it lasted, but it didn't even last one shave so... yeah. You really weren't very careful with this one, Tweezerman. Everyone should be aware of this possibility when you buy one of these, because I'm not the only one who's reported this. For such an integral part of my kit, I'll pay another 10 bucks for something that will last longer than one shave.
  313. Good price for a badger brush. It looses a lot of hair. It's lost so much I think I can see the difference in the fullness of the brush.
  314. My last brush lasted three years, but I lost it over my last trip and had to buy a new one. It is a great brush that makes lathering a joy.
  315. ok this is the 4th brush i've purchased in the past 5 or so years. all of the others fell apart b/c i did not know that you're supposed to hang them upside down so that the water drips out. i just assumed that they only lasted 6 months to a year. my mistake.<br /><br />I've had this one for a couple of months now and it works like it is supposed to work. it puts lather on my face and i didn't have to pull more than a few bucks out of my pocket. winner.
  316. So I bought this new shaving brush for my husband. He says it lathers really well. The one complaint he did have is that it has a funky smell at first when it's wet. Smells similar to a skunk (I smelled it myself):/ After using it numerous times, the smell isn't as bad. Would have given it 5 stars if it didn't smell.

It's also a great value considering many of the other good brushes are twice the price or more.

  321. Exactly as described. Shipped promptly.
  322. It smelled awful even after several washings with shampoo, and it lost about 20 hairs every time I used it. It lathered just fine, I just couldn't stand the smell. For a few dollars more, I decided to purchase an Omega brush, and I expect it to perform much better. If you don't mind the smell and the hair loss, go for it. Not for me though.
  323. I bought this brush to replace a dinky Art of Shaving brush included in one of their starter kits, and I'm very pleased. The brush is large, holds water and shaving cream well, does not shred (beyond a few stray hairs in the first couple of uses), and does not retain any odor. It feels great on my skin, too. I would advise anyone purchasing this brush to make sure they shake as much water out after shaving as possible, and to hand it upside down for storage. Great product, great price!
  324. As some other have pointed, the brush does loose some bristles intially but it did stop after a while. The only things I did not like about the bursh - The handle is very small. And the brush is very thick and holds up a lot of foam from getting to the face. Otherwise, it is a great brush for the price.
  325. I have a thick stubble and coarse hair. The bristles on this brush began falling out immediately. I had to discontinue use otherwise I would have been forced to stop using it by the bald spots. Nice novelty to have to show off in the bathroom but its not practical. Especially if you need to shave before work. Maybe a good toy for a man who is retired and has no where to be in the morning. But for the &#34;rest of us&#34; 8-5ers.... not good.
  326. I'm very happy with this brush and I've been using it daily now for a month. It whips up a great lather and I've tried it with Taylor's Eton College cream, and a concoction of regular old soap mixed with Kiss My Face shaving cream and a couple drops of glycerin which both work wonderfully with it. All that said, it isn't the softest badger brush around, comparing it to one I bought for my father a few years back (although that one cost over 3 times as much) and it is pretty small too, so don't expect miracles out of it. For the price, it's tough to beat and so far seems pretty well made although it has lost a hair here and there. Not really a big deal to me. It holds a good amount of water within the hair after soaking in a hot bowl full for making a great warm lather after a shake or two.
  327. This is my first brush. I like that it has the wood handle, and is fairly soft. I would recommend this, especially for a first time user like myself.
  328. Since it's animal hair, it may have an odor to it initially. What I did was soak the brush in a bowl of water with some dish washing liquid for an hour or so. You may need to do it twice but it worked for me. That goes for any animal hair brush.

Highly recommended if you're on a budget, or if you're looking for a \\"starter\\" or travel brush that might get a little beaten up.
  337. I've had my brush for a little over 2 months now and it's actually the only one I've bought. YES, it does loose a few hairs the first few times around, YES, you do need to buy a stand for it, and YES, it does smell like a wet dog the first time you get it wet and it feels a little spiky on the face. But those problems are not permanent; the brush gets better with each use and it definitely gets the job done. I say, if you can afford a better quality brush get it, if you're on a budget and want something that just works then add this brush to your cart.
  338. worked for a bit; then it fell apart.. the brush from the handle. glued it back together and works well ( assuming it doesnt fall apart again )<br /><br />it works well enough but i have to take off 2 stars for quality .. it shouldn't fall apart after a month of use. i hope this is just a defect not a manufacturing issue
  339. i'd never used a shaving brush like this and i wanted to try it out. i think it did a decent job, though i've never used any other one, so i can't really compare it to anything. personally, i ended up going back to an electric razor. it just takes too much time and effort to do a classic shave, in my opinion. but maybe i didn't give it enough of a fair attempt. i only tried it for a few weeks.
  340. For the price this Tweezerman shaving brush can't be beat. The Badger hair bristles are stiff enough to deliver a nice lather of shaving soap without being too stiff and hurting the face, or too soft and just smearing the shaving soap. I have now used this brush a couple times and I haven't noticed the loss of a single hair from the brush. The finish on the wood handle is holding up really nice and the hairs are easy to clean. I haven't noticed any odd odors some have complained about. Care of the brush is pretty straightforward. The manufacturer recommends rinsing in warm water and drying either hanging it upside down or laying it on its side. You do NOT want to dry this brush upright on its handle or you will likely see problems some have noted in their reviews here, such as loss of hairs and premature wear on the wood handle's finish. When I use this brush I grip the bulb of the wood handle. I do not grip the back of the handle. I believe this gives better control over the brush and helps maintain the integrity of the Badger hair knot. When cleaning the Badger hairs, rinse out all the shaving soap under warm water. There is no need to rinse under hot water which will only serve to weaken the glue holding the Badger hair knot to the wood. I lay the brush on its side to air dry, which is recommended by the manufacturer (as well as hanging upside down). Doing this keeps water from soaking into and sitting on the wood base to which the Badger hair knot is glued and thereby causing premature separation of the knot from the wood. Overall, with proper care, this shaving brush looks like it will give me great service for a long time to come. For the money this is excellent!
  341. Works the shave soap into a fine lather. I would have given it 5 stars however it lost a fair amount of bristles when I first started using it.
  342. This is my third shave whisk. My first, from Crabtree & Evelyn, lasted about 6 years and then was accidentally left at a hotel.<br /><br />My second, I forget where it was sourced, gave up chunks of bristles within a month, and was completely unusable.<br /><br />This, my third, has been durable. I've had it for 6 years, and lost no bristles. I don't hang it from a rack like it should, but I rinse it well and shake out the rinse water after every use. I have lost maybe one bristle per year, which is fine.<br /><br />The bristle head is well formed, and it creates a thick lather. The brush itself is soft to the touch, but can dab foam through my beard, or spread it along a clean line when just trimming.<br /><br />The price of this brush is excellent. I would recommend this brush to anyone wishing to whip up their own shaving cream in the mornings.

  347. Edited: I have been using the brush for about two months now. It still works great. I lose a couple of hairs when I shave with it. I don't know if that is normal two months into using it. It still blows the board head brushes away. I upgraded to a better brush. This brush is still a good low cost brush to start out with. I just wanted something better as my shaving education has progressed. This is a great little brush. It cost me about thirteen dollars w/shipping. I have a boars head brush as well and this blows the boars head brush away by leaps and bounds. I am sure I will purchase other badger hair shaving brushes. This is a great low price alternative to boars hair brushes which cost about the same. It lathers up well and doesn't take long to build a thick creamy lather. Don't let the price fool. Its a decent quality brush. Its good for a beginner to wet shaving like me, who is looking for an inexpensive solution. Just rinse the brush out thoroughly and gently towel dry it. Let it rest on it side to dry if you do not have a stand for your razor and shaving brush. I usually let it soak in the sink with my shaving bowl as I shower. That warms up the brush and provides a warm sooth lather to the face. I use real shaving-shaving cream and vanderhagen shaving soap. Both are great low cost products and I don't have any issues with them. Great brush for the price. Good for beginners.
  348. I have been using an Omega Boar Hair brush, and while it does a great job whipping up later (Proraso / Soap Puck) it did not seem to do a great job with applying the lather to the face or lightly scrubbing/prepping the hair for shaving. The Tweezermans brush exceeded my expectations in lather application and provided great face prep as well. I don't think i will go back to boars hair brushes again.

  357. I bought this Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush in June 2011. During the first week of use after a couple of shaves it fell apart although I was placing it upside down for it to dry. I still use it without the handle but it is a bit uncomfortable. The bristles are great but the glue was not strong enough. I just emailed Tweezerman at their website to see what they say. Tweezerman emailed me back and stated that I should include a note and ship the item back to them at an address they provided me (NY). I went to the post office and for $3.00 I got a box and shipped the shaving brush with a copy of the email that they had sent me. Shortly thereafter Tweezerman delivered a brand new brush in the box to my home. I am very satisfied with their warranty. The badger hair is very nice and soft. And sure is a lot easier and better than using your hands to lather your face with shaving cream.
  358. I bought this brush [[ASIN:B000G647Y8 Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush]] as my first Badger hair brush. I had been using an excellent Boar bristle brush given to me by a fellow wet shaver.   361. I travel on business. I am just bloody sick and tired of spending large sums on small cans of shaving cream. So I remembered my dad, 50 years ago, using a shaving brush and soap, and I realized that shaving soap is not a cream or liquid. Voila! I went to WalMart and bought their shaving brush and soap. The soap is perfectly adequate (for about $1.75), but their brush features PIG hair/fur/pubies/whatever (about $5). Nevertheless, I went for it; how could you not? I shaved. Feh. The brush stays wet, leaves soap trails, doesn't do the job. I was forlorn. That is, until I visited MY Amazon (or, it ought to be) and found this brush. My Dad used a badger brush. Now I use one - this one. It works up a lather, spreads it smoooooth, and then balances on its one foot to preen while I shave. Best of all: when I rinse it off and shake it (the brush) a few times, it mysteriously dries. Perfect for travel. The TSA envies me. Get it. David Block

  367. Some 8 months ago I took the plunge into switching from a cartage razor to a double edge setup. The first few times I used it I noticed 2 or 3 shed hairs and absolutely none after the first week.   372. Excellent product, slightly smaller brush head than the more expensive brushes available but it's really not a big deal. Soft and well made, the perfect travel brush. If your travels are mostly to places you'll never see again, a simple plastic or wire hanger will suffice. Keep it clean, hang it bristles down, and get years of use for only a few dollars.

  386. This is my first time using the Badger brush, and at first my face was having a lot of allergic reaction to it. I didn't let the brush soak in the water long enough and VOILA that was my problem. The lathering was so much better on my face than the boar brush, because it's a lot softer. I bought OMEGA boar brush, but the stiffness was overwhelming. You have to understand that i don't shave often so i need to buy a brush that breaks in faster. I LOVE BOTH BOAR AND BADGER BRUSH, but the second time i used it, the lathering was really good, although i still need to learn how to lather the soap better since it became too watery.   387. I've used this brush twice now. It's amazing how comfortably sharp the tips of the bristles are. I can feel it exfoliating without feeling like it's scratching my face up. Several bristles fell out on the first usage, I guess it was just breaking in. The handle is glossy smooth, which made me have to grip harder when mixing shaving lather and cramped my hand just a bit in the process. But all of this is new to me. The shave itself wasn't perfect either, so I'm clearly leaning and I'm sure I'll get better with both the shaving and lathering.<br /><br />I mention these sort-of \\"negative\\" aspects to give anyone else who's as new to brush/DE shaving an idea of what they may expect on their first usage, and to not worry.<br /><br />I used this with the [[ASIN:B001JHEY14 Proraso Shaving Soap, Ultra Sensitive Skin 5.2 oz (147 g)]] and on my first attempt, I swished it around gently enough to cover the top of all the bristles, then I swished the brush around in an empty cup with a dab of water. I created so much foam I was able to do 3 passes and I still had plenty of shaving cream lather left over. I'm not sure if I was able to get so much because of the quality of the brush bristles or because of the Proraso.
  388. In short this brush didn't even last me a year. I liked it when it was not broken, worked really well. This was my first brush, so it may have been improper use and/or care as others are saying of us novices.<br /><br />I am buying a second one now to replace my broken one and see how it goes.
  389. Good brush. I will get another when my current one wears out someday. 2017 Update. The brush is still going strong. I'm ordering a second one so I can put it in my Dopp kit.
  390. I personally enjoy/prefer the brush and cake over canned shaving cream. If you have to shave you should at least get some pleasure out of it. If you have looked in the various mall stores for a good shaving brush they tend to run between $30-$50 for a Badger or Boar, or mix bristle brush, more if you want a top quality 100% badger bristle. This one at $15 is a steal. Yes you can pay more, but why? Especially, if as I do you rotate your brushes, it can be a pricey undertaking. I have had this particular brush for about a year now and can attest that it has held up well and got the job done.
  391. Very well worth the price. I've been using it for over a year now and it's still in good shape. There's minimal shedding of hair. I wonder if other reviewers complaining of shedding have gotten a defected brush.<br /><br />I haven't used a stand for it yet. I just dry it on it's side on top of a towel, then turn it brush-side-up when it's mostly dry.<br /><br />I use this with Proraso shaving cream. Quite refreshing!
  392. This brush feels great brushing the lather frok the Old Bond Street on my face. Go for the real thing and leave the fake stuff for toys. After 2 years hair is in good shape as well as the handle. I use this alot as I have to stay clean shaven for work and I expect it to last several more years. I hear you are not supposed to set these upside down on the handle after using so they will dry good. I roll mine in a couple paper towels after each use and put Iit back in the drawer. Works perfect. Handle still looks great and hair is straight. Highly recommended for someone who has to shave alot. Don't make shaving a chore, make it enjoyable.

  399. I was pleasantly surprised with this purchase as some reviews claimed they had hairs fall out or the brush was harsh... I'd like to share that the brush is nice and soft and after using it several times since I've received it I have yet to have any hairs come out. I'll note for those new to these brushes it is animal so it has a wet animal smell to it which goes away more and more after each use. I've read borax will get rid of this very quickly or you can use shampoo/handsoap which I did and it got rid of most of it immediately. Holds plenty of water and dries quickly after rinse & a couple shakes.

  401. I've purchased this item three times now. It's small but does it's job as well as I could've expected. Bristles weren't super soft but not terribly abrasive either. Aside from that, again, not a bad product.
  402. I originally bought this brush for my son, with hopes of getting him interested in wet shaving. It has become part of my brush assortment (7). This is the least expensive brush I own and does a GREAT job whether used in bowl (scuttle) lathering or face lathering. The bristles are soft on the face yet firm with a bit of backbone. It is an all around low cost work horse of a brush. The fit and finish on mine is \\"fairly poor\\". It had one crack in it when it arrived and has developed another crack since, both go into the handle from the ferrule area. Additionally the manufacturer left the base of the handle in a rough sawn condition and simply varnished over it without sanding it out. I've often thought that I probably own the ugliest Tweezerman out there... I could of easily returned it to Amazon but I kept it anyway. Glad for it, because I value this little beasty!! I take it when traveling and do simple face lathering shaves with it using shaving cream (Proraso or Speick). Works great. If it came up lost, I wouldn't loose sleep over it. I would certainly buy another Tweezerman to replace it. It's a great little brush for under 14 bucks! Look elsewhere if you want to purchase \\"eye candy\\" or a brush that might give you \\"high end\\" product self-satisfaction or bragging rights. This little guy is simply GREAT FOR WHAT IT IS... so I still gave it 5 stars... even though mine is kind of an ugly duck.
  403. It's cheap, so it won't be the &#34;best&#34; brush you can buy. If you are starting out with wet shaving, then this brush is a good start. Once you figure out if wet shaving is for you, just get a better brush. I, for one, prefer the stiffness of this brush as i helps exfoliate and lift up some ingrown hairs Edit: The first brush worked ok for about a year and a half and now just sheds non-stop. I ordered a second brush and it seems that they simply glued the badgers anus to a wood handle. I guess that I'll be upgrading.
  404. I started using a shaving brush years ago. I discovered that a shaving brush works the lather into my whiskers much better than finger tips and provides more uniform coverage for a more comfortable shave with any of the razors I've used.   405. Amazing brush for $12. It shed like a mofo when I first bought it, but mainly because it's OVER-PACKED with badger bristle. Is it annoying? Not to me.. I payed $12.... and I received a brush with almost 2x bristles of brushes I saw at Art of Shaving for 3x the price and same quality hair... so no I have NO complaints. After a few months the shedding stopped, I still get maybe 1 loose bristle every once in a while but nothing serious. After 3 years of constant use and abuse, my brush is beautiful. No mold, no excessive bristle loss, creates a beautiful and full lather on a drop of a proraso shaving cream, and still fuller than the brushes sold as new from shaving stores I hit up to window shop. SO, will I tell you to buy this?? HELL YES!!!!! For the price it can't be beat. Don't worry about the shedding it stops and your brush still works and looks great after.

  407. Really 4 stars, read on. Just having started on DE shaving on november 2011, my first set of purchases includes this brush. (Merkur 180 long razor, 10 pack of merkur razor blades and proraso shaving soap). This brush feels great on the skin and gets you lathered up exquisitely. On my first lather I take about 2 minutes, because I just love the exfoliating feeling I get, kinda like the feeling you get when you go to a spa. I usually don't skimp on taking some extra time lathering up and brushing my face with this. I also use this even when I am not shaving, for a quick face rinse (with soap of course), when I am going out or have some company. I am sure the smoothness and lack of irritation on my skin has a lot to due with the brush. First couple of uses it does smell a little odd, but I like the smell and it goes away quickly with a couple of shaves. Also hairs do fall off initially and throughout the life of the brush, but it seems to diminish as you go. About a hair per shave I'd say, which isn't very much. With that said, this isn't a bad beginner brush, in fact it does its job perfectly. You could probably keep this for a long time. And if I we're more frugal I probably would. However, I can tell there are better brushes, albeit at a higher price. In short, best brush for beginners and best bang for buck. If you wan't better quality, you will have to pay double or even triple. I will be purchasing a more expensive brush in the future, but I really don't need to for now. Happy shaving gentlemen!

  409. I followed the \\"experts\\" advice but this brush continues to lose bristles from shave one. I just started \\"real shaving\\" after years of cartridges and $$$ and canned foam. Tried gently rinsing the brush, light shaking it, and being very gentle but still ended up covered in bristles. After using the brush and following the expert's advice on rinsing and shaking, and hanging it up to dry, handle end up, the brush now looks like a rounded shrub, with stray bristles sticking out the sides at odd angles. Despite the brush, though, I had a very enjoyable experience shaving with my new DE razor, getting a nice, smooth, close shave. My better half noticed the difference immediately! I am hooked!   412. This is a great little badger hair brush. I also have a boars hair brush and the difference is night and day. The badger hair makes a quick and thick lather. Feels softer on the face.   413. I am a light shaver, 2-3 times a week. A 12-pack of Mach-3 lasts me about 1.5 years, no kidding. So when I went to buy some more, I was really shocked by the \\"new\\" price and spending that much for blades. I did a little research, and found out that Dad's way is actually the 2nd closest shave you can get next to a straight razor. I am not ready for a straight razor, we learn to crawl before we run marathons. This is my first brush. I did not want to spend a lot because I was not sure I was going to stick with this method. Guess what? I am never going to anything else. This method is great! I bought a Merkur razor, Gilette 7 o'clock blades, Proraso shaving cream, and Proraso pre/after shaving cream. I wet the brush, shake off excess water, swish the brush around in the cup, and it takes me about 30 seconds to get a good lather going. I rinse the brush under warm, running water, squeeze the bristles through my forefinger and thumb, shake off any excess, and hang it upside down in the brush/razor holder I bought. I have absolutely no problems with bristles falling out or wood cracking. Being a newbie, I do not have other brushes to compare this experience to. I expect the brush to last, at least 3-5 years. I am considering buying the Parker brush for comparison. I really like the Proraso products. I like the facial sensation the shaving cream gives. I did use the pre/after shave cream before lathering up for a couple of weeks, but found no difference between using it beforehand and not using it. Results may differ with heavy shavers. As an aftershave cream, I wish I had known about it before--alcohol-free and conditions the skin. I receive compliments on how smooth my face feels even hours after I have shaved. I will buy one of those sample packs to see if there is a better blade for my face. I use this blade about three times and then flip it to the other side for 3 more shaves. I bought everything here on Amazon for a good price and quick shipping.
  414. This was my first shaving brush and I would recommend this as a starter brush for any beginner looking into getting into wet shaving. For the price you can't beat it. I have used mine daily for the past five months and it has held up well. Expect to lose a few bristles during the first week but it won't be anything dramatic. The pictures of this brush don't really do it justice. After regular use the bristles seem fuller and it takes on a much wider look than what you will see here. The bristles also become much softer over time so stick with it. When it comes to lathering, as long as you soak it for a few minutes beforehand you will have an easy time with it. I have used it with soaps and creams and it does an equally good job. I've since upgraded to an Edwin Jagger brush to try out a higher quality hair grade but this brush will still be used when I'm traveling.

  428. I have had this for two years and it is still like new. The key to these like any brush, is to rinse and spin dry them with your hands and put store them on a stand. This keeps the glue from failing and the bristles from falling out (not too mention the handle rotting). It's made of wood and hair folks. Take care of this and it will last and do the same job as the crazy expensive brushes.

The brush works very well in whipping up a lather and I am careful to store it upside down to drain and squeeze it gently to wring it out.   455. This brush is just as good as any of the high end brushes on the market. It holds together well and is very affordable.
  456. Like the title says. The brush had a heavy badger scent (smells like badger ass)but it can be removed by washing it with shampoo and conditioner a few times. Makes great lather quickly but does not retain heat as well as some of my top dollar brushes. Other than that its a great starter brush and couldent be more pleased.
  457. I've used this over a year now and think it's nice. There is no doubt I get a better shave if I use it rather than don't. The bristles are pretty nice and they work up a good lather. They also scratch up your whiskers to loosen them for the shave. The brush still looks pretty good after a year of daily use. I keep it in the shower and it dries up in a few hours. And it's a no-brainer to say but, just keep the bristles down so the water drops out, don't stand it up if it's moist.
  458. I have several brushes in my collection including silver tip badger down to a $5.00 boar bristle. As I like to alternate days, I thought thia Tweezerman would be a good middle of the road brush. As it turns out, I find it to be the least comfortable brush I have ever owned. The brissles/hair in the center of the brush actually feel prickly when attempting to lather my face. It appears to be well constructed but sheds heavily. I was very disappointed with this brush overall and could not, in good conscience, recommend it at any price point. Rather than retruning the brush, I will throw it in with my guncleaning gear.
  459. Best brush I have ever owned
  460. I can't really compare it to anything else, but this thing is capable of making a nice lather. It's cheap and the quality is nice. It lost a few bristles the first week or so, but it's been going strong for over a year now!
  461. I was a bit disappointed. I thought it would be a fuller brush, but my husband loves iit.
  462. The finer, softer bristles of badger hair do make a difference. The brush makes great lather, feels good on the face. I doubt a $50+ British brush is any better.
  463. I've had no trouble at all with this brush in the month or so since purchase. Does exactly what I want it to do; no complaints. I have no idea what a brush costing X multiples would offer that this brush doesn't, other than vanity frills like an ivory handle or some such. Update (11/29/10): The sleeve that holds the bristles popped out a year ago due to glue deterioration - I was able to glue it back in and use the brush without further incident. Now the handle is cracking where the sleeve is inserted - the brush will be unusable in short order. I took decent care of the product, drying the brush bristles down; the problem most likely is that I shave in the shower and the constant humidity did its thing on the wooden handle. Maybe that ivory handle I poo-pooed isn't such a bad idea...
  464. I use these types of brushes to clean my clipper and beard trimmer. They work much better than anything else I could find. I shave my head with a clipper and use this brush to clean it along with the hair around my ears and neck. <br /> <br />I had an older plastic brush for like 10 years and it started to shed big time, so I needed a new one. As others have stated, a quality brush of this type is not cheap. I didn't do exhaustive research, but this does seem to be a really good deal. Anyway, I've used it a few times and it works well. The bristles are very soft when I use it to brush off hair around my ears and neck.
  465. Seems like a good deal for a beginner shaving brush...it's the number 1 or 2 seller. But newbies to wet shaving would be served much better with an Omega or Semogue boar brush. This product constantly sheds bristles, feels very scratchy against my face, and makes it difficult to lather soap/creams.
  466. It's the first shaving brush I've ever used, and I have to say I'm liking it. It has lost a few bristles, but nothing to be concerned over. It's really a great brush.
  467. My husband likes it, although he's not going to switch to shaving with a straight razor.
  468. This only the second shaving brush I've used, the first being a really cheap boar hair brush. The Tweezerman is much better. It cleans and dries much more quickly, and it doesn't lose as many bristles per shave as the cheaper one. I'm giving it a four because it's a the first badger hair brush I've used, and perhaps the more expensive ones do a better job. If you're just getting started with wet-shaving, I'd go with the Tweezerman. You don't want to invest in a really expensive brush, then end up not liking it. This one does its job and is not overpriced.
  469. This isn't as nice as the Omega brush I usually use. I got it for travel. That said, it's really quite good. Whips up a good lather, nice feel to the badger bristles. Best price for a badger brush that I found.
  470. I started wet shaving with a safety razor about a year ago and used a cheap boar bristle brush. This is much different in that it shakes water off very quickly so I've had to get used to keeping it wetter than my instincts want. Works great with my shave soap, and after the first few weeks it's not shedding hairs or anything. I'm following the advice of other reviewers to always let it dry with the bristles down so it doesn't soak through and damage the wood handle.
  471. I know that many folks will tell you that you can buy better shaving brushes that won't lose their bristles, and I'm pretty sure that you can. However, I've been lathering my shaving soap by hand and then applying it to my wetted face for a few months now and I think that is far superior to lathering with a brush. Then again, I'm a mid-20s guy and not a more aged fellow who has been doing this for awhile, so maybe I just don't see the benefits of brush lathering.
  472. I have to say after trying a few different things, first your standard razor, then, a gillette power fusion, then an electric razor, that I think I've found a new winner.<br /><br />First of all, I thought I'd try an electric razor because I wanted to see if one actually worked. The electric razor I have, is the [[ASIN:B001DKMY9Q Panasonic ES8243A Men's 4-Blade (Arc 4) Wet/Dry Rechargeable Electric Shaver with Nanotech Blades, Blue]]. I found that using that on conjunction with Afta Pre-electric shave, I end up with what looks like a day old shave, when comparing it to shaving with a DE razor (using a 100 pack Feather blades). Without Pre-electric shave, forget it. It just didn't work all that well, but at the time, I was just too lazy to go back to my original razor to shave.<br /><br />What I like about this product, is that it completely wakes me up in the morning. It feels great to shave like this. Unfortunately, it's back to the old problems I had with an original razor: I cut myself. So much for a \\"safety\\" razor. I don't know how safe it is, but hey, whatever. It works, it's comfortable, and applying the soap can get pretty sloppy.
  473. Awesome brush for the price. Makes an excellent thick lather and is durable and easy to maintain. Would definitely recommend to a friend.

  484. Made very well, holds up great with no loss of bristles and no problems with a cracking base. Just remember to shake out excess water after shaving and store it bristles down (on a stand, which you should definitely get). I'd definitely recommend it.
  485. I'd feel bad giving a $10 brush a 1 star rating, so I'll give it 2 because of the price tag.<br /><br />Listen guys, this thing is not a quality brush. It sheds like a Siberian Husky in a Texas summer. I constantly have to fish out hairs from my soap dish with a tweezers. Incidentally, the \\"Tweezerman\\" company specializes in making and selling tweezers. Coincidence? Or mastermind conspiracy to boost tweezers sales? Probably coincidence, but still a real nuisance.<br /><br />Mind you, I have a stand for it so I can store it upside-down, I shave with distilled water, I am very gentle with it, and it still keeps shedding.<br /><br />So... IF you're just starting out wet-shaving and aren't sure if you're in for the long haul, AND you're totally comfortable picking hairs out of your soap dish until you're left with an empty brush handle, AND you only have $20 in your bank account - half of which needs to cover meals for the next week, then I'd STILL suggest you stick to ramen noodles for a while so you can buy a better brush than this one.<br /><br />Cheers.
  486. I have one of these and am buying one for my son. I've had it for almost a year and I think it stopped shedding after about 9 months. Had I paid a lot for this that would bother me but for what I paid, I would recommend this to anyone who wants to try a shaving brush. I've yet to try a more expensive brush so I can't speak to that. But I love the feel of this brush. I don't have sensitive skin so I don't want softer bristles.   490. I'm about four months into this brush and it started shedding like crazy. I'm talking about five hairs per shave. There was no stink to the brush like I have read about badger brushes. As far as shedding, around 4 hairs fell out while shampooing. After that was done I soaked the bristles in hot water while prepping my face. Used the brush to lather and do a three pass shave. Worked GREAT. I like it even more now that I have used it. Highly Recommended.

  497. I'm not sure what is the difference between this and some of the brushes some folks pay a hundred bucks for. The savings on the shavings is wonderful! Now on to this product review with my background laid out.   507. I wish I could recommend this item, but I can't. For ~$13 it's definitely an &#34;affordable&#34; alternative if you're new to wet shaving. This was the first brush I bought and I bought it precisely because it was so cheap. I was...disappointed to say the least. It is NOT soft. Don't get me wrong, it's not horribly hard, but it's definitely not soft either. It is also not very big, just OK sized.<br /><br />if you can afford something in the ~$25 range, go for one of the cheaper Parker Safety Razor brushes. Their entry level brushes cost about that much. That was the second brush I bought and it's well worth the ~$10 difference! It's really soft, makes better lather, and it's bigger.<br /><br />Anyway, I don't hate this brush (and I still use it on occasion), but I definitely recommend Parker's before this one if you can spend a bit more.
  508. This brush sheds bristles every time I use it. Gets the job done though and is good for the price.
  509. This is a very cheap and functional brush. It doesn't feel like silvertip or other high quality badger bristle to me. The bristle is stiff and hasn't softened after three years of hot shaving. It lathers OK but drips water too much for my liking. The lather is also not as fine as a softer bristled brush in my opinion. All that said it's functional and I shaved with it successfully for three years, so if your budget is tight and you still desire a shaving brush it will work for you and will be satisfactory. I give it three stars as a result!

  511. Badger hair shaving brushes are not the cheapest items in the world. Not to mention usually you get what you pay for; however I have to say that this brush bucks that trend. The brush does the job at a price MUCH better than the competitors. My one minor issue: -the first brush I bought repeatedly would lose hairs each time I used it. I hoped it would stop at some point but this went on for a month or so. In a strange sort of luck, I managed to leave the brush behind on a business trip and had to purchase a new one. The new brush works like a charm. In a nutshell, I would not hesitate, if you need a shaving brush and do NOT want to pay an arm and a leg then this is the brush for you. On a side note, if you are considering this brush you should also consider (if you have not already) switching to a Safety Razor rather than the economy razors you find in the supermarket. My shaving experience and outcome has changed considerably as a result of using this brush as well as the safety razor. My recommendation for a safety razor: Merkur Classic Safety Razor, Straight - #178 As far as shaving soap and blades goes: check out eBay as well as Amazon

  516. Update: After using this brush for nearly 8 years I have concluded that, while functional, this brush can be outperformed by many others at a similar price point. Check out the Omega boar and synthetic brushes which are larger and higher quality, and will create a better lather and hold more of it. These are available on Amazon for around the same price, and they're made in Italy! Generally it's best to avoid cheap badger brushes and this is definitely one of them. After upgrading to a $30 Stirling Soap Company badger brush I see that there is hardly a comparison between cheap and good badger. for my first foray into traditional DE wetshaving, i purchased this brush, along with a Merkur Classic #178 and some Col. Conk soap as recommended by a list of shaving products here on amazon. I dont have any experience with another brush against which to compare, but this brush has worked very well for me in the week or so i have been using it. it looks smaller to other brushes i have seen in video reviews, but none the less it creates a nice smooth lather once you get the motion down. Stopped losing hairs after a few weeks of regular use. This brush is a great value since it costs far less than any others on Amazon and does what it promises. that being said, i will buy a nicer one in the future, which is what im sure most of the people who buy this do.

  535. In my ~ 20 years of shaving I found that using a shaving brush and shaving cream is much more likely to produce a clean shave free of irritations. It's also the only way to shave for a Renaissance man!

I was recently given an Escali which looks nearly identical (I wouldn't be surprised if they are made in the same factory), but the bristles on the Escali are much softer than the Tweezerman. I've only used the Escali a couple of times so I can't comment on long term durability, but it's losing a lot of bristles already. I suspect this item either varies in quality, or the quality has degraded over since it was introduced.

  594. I've had this brush going on 4 years now and it's excellent. Never store it or let it dry with the bristles up. You need to get a holder that will let the bristles hang down as the brush dries so it doesn't damage the part holding it all together. A little bit of care for your tools makes them last a long time.<br /><br />I've seen brushes sell for $50+ and that's crazy when this does the trick. You'll loose a bristle here and there, but that's normal wear and tear. Just remember to store and dry it properly, and don't try to strongarm the soap. Get the brush wet and rub it against the soap till a bit of lather forms. I prefer the Proraso shaving soap.

That has pretty much tapered off at this point. Now it only loses maybe one or two hairs per shave. I would warn anyone with really sensitive skin that this brush is pretty stiff, which was surprising to me. But, I like the scratch on my face. This is a great brush for the price and you won't find a better one at this price point. Not enough to notice the depletion in looking at the brush or feel a difference in the function but, enough to notice and this can be a bit of a problem when they get stuck in between the blades causing an uneven shave. Over all it's a good product and the hair loss isn't enough of a problem to warrant returning or replacing it.

  611. Do not hesitate to buy this brush. I have shaved with a straight razor for over half of my life and done the rounds with some very expensive brushes.   612. If you consider a Corvette a starter car because it's not a Ferrari or a Ford F350 a starter truck because it's not a dump truck then yes, this is a starter brush. You can purchase more luxurious and use-specific brushes but that doesn't take away from the quality of this brush. The $60 Parker silver tip chrome handle on this site is no where near as good a brush and cost four times more. I made the mistake of thinking this is a \\"starter\\" brush because of the price and some of the reviews on this site. Yes, it's very inexpensive compared to what's out there but that doesn't mean you'll outgrow it and want or need a more expensive brush. Personally, I left this brush in the shower every day for months, most of the time resting bristles up. I just give it a good shake and it's held up great. Not a single hair has fallen out and despite being left in a damp shower it's still in perfect condition. The water has not affected the wood or glue one bit. One thing I won't do is leave it in a closed ziploc bag when wet when travelling. I assume that would be bad. Other than that, the best advice I can give to anyone using a brush is soak it in warm/hot water for a few minutes before each use. When done, rinse out all the soap and give it a good shake. Do that with any and every shaving brush. FYI - this brush fits perfectly into the $22 Col. Conk stand available on this site. Because shaving brushes don't cost as much as a Ferrari or a dump truck, I also have some more expensive ones that I do use more often. I won't name them because you don't need to spend more money to get a better shave. The only thing \\"starter\\" about this is the price, not the quality. I'm not trying to talk you out of a specialty brush, I just don't want you to feel you \\"need\\" one to get a better shave. Experiment with blades, razors, soaps, creams, oils and aftershaves first. If you have any money left and you still feel like it, then feel free to \\"upgrade.\\" Keep in mind that the bigger the brush the more likely you are to get shaving cream up our nose or in your ears. Bottom line, the Tweezerman brush makes a great gift or even an \\"upgrade\\" for yourself. Happy shaving.
  613. As I stated in the title, great low cost quality brush. Not much else to say about it. You will lose a few hairs in the beginning, that is normal. I have used it now for 2 months and love it. Just take care of it and it should last a good long while. Rinse with clean water then gently squeeze out excess; let air dry.

  627. At first, the brush was shedding like crazy because of how I was using it. I was hanging it to dry as recommended, but was using it with a silver bowl. I believe the silver bowl's shape was destructive to the brush. Realizing this, I dedicated a coffee cup to the task. I put a puck of shaving soap into the coffee cup and leave it there. A splash of water and lotion on top of the soap in the cup and a few swirls of the brush and I have a very nice lather to shave with. I then hang it to dry with the handle towards the ceiling,
  628. Good brush for the price. After a year it has never stopped shedding though.

  638. It's a very good badger brush for the price, and I don't think a buyer would be disappointed with it. It lathers well, and seems durable. However, the pure badger hair used on this brush is a little prickly, which becomes an annoyance after a while. The handle is quite small, so if you enjoy bowl lathering, prepare for things to get a little messy. As an alternative, I would recommend an Omega boar brush, for less money. My Omega Pro 49- about $15 on Amazon- was softer than the Tweezerman from day one, and is only getting better, as the ends of boar bristles split with use, making the brush softer. Well broken in boar brushes become incredibly soft, and still have lots of backbone for face lathering.[[ASIN:B000CB8Q4Y White Handled Omega Professional Boar Hair Shaving Brush]] Maybe some day I'll get a really nice silvertip badger brush. Until then, the little Tweezerman will still be used occasionally, just not as often as the Omegas.
  639. Bought this brush to use while traveling. It is everything I'd wanted! It's small enough to go in my shaving kit for travel. The bristles are soft and spread nicely, holding the lather well. In general it performs almost as well as my much more expensive badger bristle home shaving brush.
  640. I made the switch to safety razor shaving, and this brush is now part of my shaving kit. It's a nice size, and really sucks up and retains water and soap. I like how frothy the shaving soap gets when you swish it around with this brush in a mug. When applying it, you can feel your face get warm and stimulated, and your stubble being pushed outwards for a closer shave.<br /><br />I have noticed a slight musky odor, but it's not strong and will probably fade over time. A few hairs have come off as well, but again I think this is normal at first. The brush has to \\"get used to\\" being swirled around in hot water and cream. I set it on its side to dry, but there are stands you can buy to hang it so the brush part drips downward.
  641. I'm buying something else because this brush literally stinks and my bathroom reeks like ferret. I've been using it for about a week hoping the soap makes the odor go away. I'm done and it's gone.
  642. This shaving brush is great. My husband has had it for over a year now and it is still as soft as the day he bought it. It hasn't lost any bristles with use and he loves the lather he gets from using it. Highly recommended product- quality at a fraction of the price of other boar brushes.
  643. This brush was purchased through amazon. I didn't expect a great brush for the low price and I didn't get one. This was what I expected for a $15 badger brush. It's still somewhat better than a $10 boar bristle. Would be OK for a travel brush if I didn't already have one. I'll keep this one in the shower.
  644. I have used these brushes for years with no problem. One thing no one has mentioned is that if you have a problem with the brush you can send it to the manufacturer and they will replace it, no questions asked. I found this out last year when my brush came out of the handle. I contacted them and they sent me a new brush. When Tweezerman says lifetime guarantee, they mean it.
  645. When I got this a few days ago I was happy with purchase as I thought it look and felt good for the price. Day one cleaned it with shampoo and used it, worked OK but sheds hairs like hell. Day two used it again and no longer happy with it as the brush sheds hair like a long hair dawgg. The amount of hair inserted into the wood handle is barely .5 inch and not glued properly this is not a quality product, like they say you get what you pay for, your mileage might vary with this product... To me is not even worth trying to sent it back. \\"I would not recommend this brush to anyone\\" Back to using my father's forty years old brush, the head is not as full as I remember it as a kid but the thing don't shed and it is still working.

I bought this brush to take the abuse of being in my travel kit. Any brush in there, regardless of quality, is going to wear out within a year. This one is fantastic for that purpose--I won't mind buying another one every few months, and it's not a bad brush at all.

It has badger bristles to hold more water and combined with a good shave soap (not the cheap stuff you buy at discount stores), will give your face a good prep before you shave. My teen-age son recently started using this too so I guess I'll have to buy another one soon so he can have his own. It's a fantastic brush for the money. It makes your face feel great and holds the soap lather well for a second lather if you want a really close shave. My suggestion is to not skimp on the other stuff. Buy a good stand to hold the brush, a durable double-edged safety razor, and some quality soap. I bought the Col. I warm the mug with the soap inside under the running hot water while I pre wet my face then with the brush not too wet I whip up the soap to a lather and paint it on my beard working it in real good to get a nice even lather. That soft brush and warm lather feels good on those crisp mornings. For the money you won't go wrong with this brush. I wash it out real good when done shaving and hang it bristles down to dry. I've had it for over a year now and it still looks good and works as it should.

  717. I'm generally a pretty harsh critic, but this brush for the twelve bucks or whatever is a very good deal when compared to badger brushes costing hundreds of dollars. Maybe those are the greatest things ever made but I'll never know because for the money this brush works really well. It holds enough water easily to develop a nice lather on a hard shave soap, and it's stiff enough to raise the stubble like you want to when shaving. It's not the softest brush ever, but I don't think you want it to be. It did lose some hairs for the first few months, but not that many. It did also have a rather strong badger odor to it when wet, but that eventually went away. That would be my one quibble with the brush that it would be nice if they would improve. I've been using it for over a year and it's held up well, though I do hang it up upside down on a stand like you're supposed to so water doesn't sit on and break down the adhesive. I'm giving it 5 stars because of the value for the money. Along with an inexpensive razor like [[ASIN:B001VD7VIY Double Edge Razor LORD Chrome ---GREAT VALUE---]] and some decent blades or a straight razor, it's a great way to get into wet shaving. Every guy should try it instead of being in the \\"now with 5 blades!\\" cartridge rat race. Try a blade assortment to find out what type of blades you like if you go with a double edge razor. I've found wet shaving to be so much better than shaving with disposable cartridges that I'm considering going to a straight razor.

  726. I will invest more money in a shaving brush next time. This was inexpensive, and i know very little about brushes so i tried it. My husband is happy with it, but I've noticed it loses hairs with each use. If this stops over time I'd buy it again. It is soft (but firm) and looks nice (updated January 2016... not only has it not stopped with time, but the shedding has increased. I'm giving up on this one and investing in another brand. Here's what I've learned: First, there are all different types of bristles. synthetic, horse hair, badger, boar bristle...Good for different types of soaps or shaving creams, and also different types of beards. Who knew? Some arrive smelling like a dead animal, apparently, but I never had that problem with this brush. It smelled neutral. I'm not actually particularly worried about bristle type right now. I just want to find a quality brand that doesn't shed excessively. second: care and storage of the brush can affect shedding and fiber breakage and resiliency, although in the case of this brush, I have cared for it and stored it as recommended... I think its knot is defective. third: I found some basic brands to check out. Within brand names there are often different sizes of brushes, with different uses. bigger is not necessarily better. (I like the size of this one, very usable.Smaller is not necessarily better either. In fact, beware of very small brushes. Check the size when ordering if possible. Within brands there is often also a huge range in price. Ive found very inexpensive to hundreds of dollars. Some brands I'm looking at: Simpsons, Omega, Kent, Parker, and... the one I've just ordered, Muhle.) I hope this helps!
  727. This shaving brush does the job. Unlike other reviewers I did not find any problem with hairs falling out of the brush. One or two fell out the first week but not for the remaining two months I've been using it.

  739. Say that 10 times fast! I picked this little gem up because my Baxter Best Badger Brush was too soft for some of the harder soaps that I use. The Baxter is a fine brush but it is way soft and flattens too easily. This one really stands up to the harder soaps. I can build an amazing lather with it. Like others have said it does shed a little the first few shaves but after that I only get an occasional hair in my cream. The smell goes away after a couple of shaves and was not that bad to start with. It is not as soft as the Baxter either. It's a little picky at first but it does smooth out a bit. But hey, it's a steal at this price! You should not expect it to be as nice as a $50+ brush. So no, it's not better than a Baxter's Best Badger Brush but it serves it's purpose and it does it cheap.
  740. I received this brush very quickly and put it to use immediately. I was able to make thick, rich, lather in a short period of time. It loses a few bristles here and there, but it hasn't been an issue yet. Very satisfied with theperformanceso far.
  741. This brush is awesome for the money, not the cleanest or the most impressive; but it's really good for a starting brush.
  742. Does its job perfectly even after hundreds of shaves.
  743. Brush worked well while it lasted. I took good care of it as mentioned in the instructions but after 7 months the knot came out from the handle. I am going to contact Tweezerman for a replacement.
  744. This is an excellent value for the money. My only complaint is very small - during the first use it did lose a few bristles, but only a few. The size & feel are very nice and it works great. The wood color is as pictured - very light. Five stars for the outstanding value.
  745. What can I say, It's a brush right? A brush that's pretty cheap right? Like the one you can get at the drug store (yes they sell them there too)<br /><br />Yes this is the same price as the one at the drug store HOWEVER, it's a million times better. This is BADGER hair, the one at the drug store is Hogs hair, yes man HOG.<br /><br />Who do you think would win the fight? Honey Badger or Pig?<br /><br />I kid, I kid...<br /><br />Seriously, this brush is great for the money, and it is real badger hair. If you don't trust me, that's cool. Get this one and the one at your local drug store, let me know whatcha think.
  746. Brush is a little better than expected. It is not equal to a $200 brush, but it cost much less. Better than boar hair.
  747. does its job well. lifts the beard up and produces a nice shave. it loses a hair or two with every shave even though i treat it as a shave brush should be. it not much of a complaint
  748. Great brush, great price. Cannot buy individual brushes in drug stores anymore. You have to buy a brush, mug, soap set and I use the brush with canned shaving cream.

  750. I have had a few brands and this Tweezerman is still holding up wonderfully unlike my others! About a year now with this guy and I get a great shave everyday! Great price as well....
  751. Really good brush lathers nice and does what it was made for only small downside is in the start it smells like wet animal but a couple of passes in a nice smelling shave cream should change that
  752. great brush!! Very little shedding and comfortable to use hold
  753. Using this and shave soap gives me the best feeling shave! I use it with my Schick hydro and it feels great!
  754. This product really does what many others do but with far less of their costs. Would for sure purchase again though it looks it will last for a long time. Great product.
  755. UPDATE: Have been using this brush for about 4 months and love it. Works great. Gets softer with time. Very usable and seems to last if you use a brush hanger, shake all water out after use and let it dry out.<br /><br />First off, I have only used this brush once but I will update my impressions as I go.<br /><br />Received Brush: Smaller than I had imagined (this is my first brush so obviously impressions will change as I get more experience with this, and other brushes) - the rounded ball part of the handle is 3/4 the size of a golf ball, very light. Wood handle may be a bit darker than picture. Ring may be more gold than in picture. Bottom edge may be not rounded as in picture. Not bad though. No bad smell. Not super soft but not too stiff either. Not silky. True to description and expectation.<br /><br />First use: Quite a few bristles came off (about 25) - didn't affect the use but just so you understand this will probably shed hairs the first couple times you use it - I would think this is normal. Brush is stiffer than I expected but it hasn't been broken in. Worked ok with Proraso shaving cream and developed an ok lather but had to really whip it for a minute (probably more technique and experience than the brush). Shed hairs in lather were noticeable but not a real issue, think the shedding will greatly reduce or stop after a day or two. Seems like a great first brush and a cheap way to get into using a brush for shaving. If I don't come to love it, I could give this to my 16 year old as his first brush (or use it for travel).
  756. Don't know how this stacks up against other badger brushes, as this is my first , but this beauty is a gem! Decided to get another brush rather abruptly after the middle bristles on my Boar Bristle fell out. Talk about a harbinger... Panicking, I searched the internet for reviews on brushes, trying to balance cost with function. This brush seemed to be the best value, as several other reviewers attested. It looked alittle small in the pictures and I was relieved when I got it that it was just right. Dries out almost immediately after a light shake while suspended in it's holder. I am happy I purchased this one!
  757. I had an Escali shaving brush before this one, and it lost hairs continuously throughout the month I used it, up until the very end when the handle fell off and it became unusable. So I needed an alternative, and one that wouldn't break the bank, so naturally I got this Tweezerman. I've been using it for about two weeks now, and in that time it has lost less hairs than the Escali did on the very first day. The knot seems thicker to me too, which is good, since it means there is more hair in the brush to hold water and lather.<br /><br />It builds an excellent lather, it holds water and lather extremely well, it's comfortable in the hand, and soft yet bristly enough on the face that it makes shaving a very pleasant experience. Really, the only complaint I can even think of is that when just removed from the package, the brush had an unpleasant odor. This is likely the \\"badger odor\\" that all such brushes are known to sometimes have. But it's a very minor problem, since all that is required to fix it is to break in the brush. This is accomplished by soaking it in water, and then building a thick lather, and leaving the brush in it for an hour or so. If necessary, this process can be repeated a few times. Doing so removes the unpleasant odor from the brush and makes it smell like the shaving soap/cream instead, and also makes the hairs softer and feel more luxurious on the face. It's a great brush, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a cheap yet quality shaving brush to start with. There's certainly no better alternative on Amazon, and I haven't seen any available elsewhere on the internet.
  758. Better than expected. My first badger hair brush - huge difference compared to a regular bristle brush. The quality was very good. They cost at least $30 on Tweezerman website.
  759. It is true that it sheds, but it is the first couple of times. After 10 shaves it never shed a hair again! This brush is for life, very durable, very soft, very, very , very good piece of work! Buy it and you will be thankful! And I don't see why you won't have it for all your life if you take care of it. Store it on the side or upside down, never with the hair pointing up. As with everything else, if you take care of it, it will serve you well. And there is ABSOLUTELY NO reason why you have to spend more money on a brush, this is as good as the $100 ones, trust me!
  760. Understandably, this is a $9 brush. Figure I'd get that out of the way first. For the price, and for a budget shopper, this is good.<br /><br />The Problem:<br />Under VERY light use, the bristle bunch broke from the handle in roughly 6 months - I don't shave on the weekends unless I'm going out, and don't always shave every weekday, depending on the schedule. I probably average 3-4 shaves a week. The bristles are held in by a glob of glue, and pressure from the being essentially forced into the handle. I've seen other brushes break, but if I were desperate, I could use it anyway because the ring is still holding them together... not going to fly with this one.<br /><br />Despite this issue, I do give Tweezerman credit that bristles rarely shed after the first month, until finally the entire unit came loose. The bristles were also a bit rough until broken in (a month or so).<br /><br />Other than this I have no complaints, but this time I've paid an extra 50% to get a better brush with better reviews (~$14)

It had that terrible badger smell linger even after soaking and washing and daily use. It sheds constantly. I have owned it for almost 2 years and now only use it as a travel brush. The bristles are very hard nd don't lather nearly as well as others. They don't hold heat or water well. The paint began chipping off and the wood began to discolor after only a couple months. I always hung it to dry, so there is no excuse for that. If you are reluctanto spend the money, it is better than nothing, but I recommend simply starting with a quality brush instead.

(It is kept in a stand and it's shaken well before it is put away.) We'll definitely update if problems arise, but so far so good!<br /><br />This would be the perfect for a DE shaving beginner or for travel. It's cheap enough that you won't cry if you lose it, and you won't wince if your pubescent teen flings it into the toilet.<br /><br />PS...If you are one of those guys that is still buying over-priced crummy cartridges for those over-priced disposable razors, don't be shy!! Grab one of these, some Proraso shave soap, a Merkur blade, some Feather or Merkur blades (for just pennies each!) and give it a try. (Those disposables have 3-6 blades for a reason - they stink!!) Look up how-to on the web. Tons of great video out there about DE shaving. Your dad and grandfather had the right idea when they went to the barber for a shave - there's nothing like it!! My husband is really glad he went back to DE shaving - his skin is much healthier and my sons are saving oodles of money! All the girls in our house also DE shave (Cremo creme for us) and we love it. I cringe when I think of all the $ we spent on cartridges - and all for crummy shaves! Give it a try - pamper yourself!

Treat it nice, and it will take care of you... for $10 instead of $60 or more for the nicer ones.
  793. When I initially bought this brush, I had read many reviews about it not holding up well. Mine has been in continuous use for 7 months and is still fine. It lost a few hairs when I first bought it, but hasn't skipped a beat since then.<br /><br />I store the brush with the bristles down, suspended in a holder I made out of a wire coat hanger. If you want something prettier, they make stands for these as well. Pointing the bristles down allows for the water to drain out of the brush better, and thus makes the brush last much longer.
  794. A few reviews state that the failure of this brush is due to improper handling, use, drying, etc. This may be the cause in many cases, however I believe there is a serious lack of quality control on these brushes. I have posted pictures showing the separation of my brush from the handle after only 2 uses. The pictures clearly show that the adhesive used was insufficient and did not contact both the handle and the brush. If it would stay together, I imagine this would be a very good product.
  795. Love it; super soft and looks like it will last for a while. Very good for the price. Would buy again.
  796. Kind of an awful product. First thing was, it turned my shave water brown. Why would they put water soluble dye in a shave brush? Second, I agree with lots of other people that it lost hairs every shave. While there are one or two reviews of the kind that a seller might stick in saying that well, you have to just hold it right and baby it, that's only going to convince someone who has never actually owned a good quality shave brush. Young 'uns may not remember this, but shave brushes were supposed to stand up when used by the \\"manly men (and I guess women?) of yore,\\" you know - miners, stevedores, mule drivers, who weren't known for their dainty treatment of their gear.<br /><br />I ended up tossing mine away. If you figure that I used it maybe five times, that's a cost of about two bucks a shave. If I calculate the hourly cost for a ten dollar brush I used for a total of maybe five minutes before going back to my broken-handled old one, it cost me about sixty bucks an hour to shave with this thing. It's not a bargain.<br /><br />I generally don't say this, but DON'T BUY THIS PRODUCT. Soaping up your bare hands and rubbing them on your beard will work just about as well.
  797. The first several times that I used this brush hairs came off it at a worrisome rate. This was both annoying and troublesome, but after about a month of use the problem is gone and I can't really tell that anything is missing. I suppose this is par for the course for a badger hair brush at this price point, but that does not make it any less unpleasant to pick stray badger hairs off your face and out of the sink.<br /><br />That said, the brush does what it's meant to do, is pleasant to use now that it no longer sheds, and it allows me to use half the shaving cream I needed to use before.<br /><br />Update after 3 months: Shedding has started to increase again and I've decided to get rid of this brush. It was a good way to decide if using a brush was right for me, but now it's time to invest in something that doesn't leave a pile of badger hair in the sink every time I shave. This brush does not seem to be made to last very long -- I've cared for it properly but it is still falling apart.
