  800. This is an ok shave brush. It is very rough for a badger haired brush and feels no different than a boar hair brush. I think it probably is a boar hair with just a couple of badger hairs. Company's can legally do that as long as they use 3 percent of what they are claiming it to be and that goes for everything even food products! It feels like an old school straw broom on your face. I dropped the brush and it broke where the bristles meet the handle so the sturdiness is somewhat questionable but for 10 bucks what can you expect? I just bought the Van Der Hagen's kit for men and it should be here tomorrow (1/11/13). I just opened the Van Der Hagen kit I ordered and the brush is SO soft compared to the Tweezerman's. I cant even describe how soft this brush really is. I would never buy another Tweezerman's brush EVER. Spend the extra 20 bucks and get the Van Der Hagen's Luxury Shave Kit. Take it from someone who has VERY sensitive facial skin. You will not regret it!!!

  824. Since this is my first brush, my take my review with a grain of salt.<br /><br />The points that I authoritatively can make are these. 90% of the &#34;animal smell&#34; went away after the first shave. The smell diminished even more after the second shave. The bristle loss, as well, was done by the second shave. I think that it shed only 1 bristle on the third shave.<br /><br />Opinions: It seems to pick up soap very well, and I can easily manage the water to soap ratio. It is easy to re-lather between passes, which makes wet-shaving much more pleasant. The handle is comfortable, but could be improved upon. The price is amazing.<br /><br />I have not tried it with a shaving cream yet. I read through many of the 1-star reviews, and have not experienced any problems with the knot, lingering smell, or sustained shedding.

  834. I've had this brush for almost two years now, and I don't have a single complaint about it, except that when I bought it on Amazon, it was about $8 more expensive. I honestly thought I paid even more than that, and still felt like I got a great deal.<br /><br />I have seen a few of the bristles fall out, as other reviewers have mentioned, but I rinse it out well, squeeze and shake it out pretty vigorously after each use, and store it standing upright (bristles facing heaven). I know this is contrary to what most people recommend, but I travel a lot, so carrying around a stand to hang it on is a hassle. Plus, since I picked it up for such a good price, replacing it will not be too big a sacrifice. All that said, I don't find an inordinate number of bristles falling out, it still foams up a great lather, and it even escorted me through a deployment in the desert.<br /><br />I like this brush so much, that I'm including it in a gift set I'm putting together for my son for his 13th birthday present. Might as well get him started right!

One thing you will want to invest in is a stand like [[ASIN:B0098NPUGY Chrome Shaving Brush Stand from Super Safety Razors]], this will keep your brush head pointing down so that it can dry and extend the length of use with your brush. Without a stand your brush wont last longer than a year. Another good thing to invest in is a brush cleaner like [[ASIN:B0016M370G SEPHORA COLLECTION Daily Brush Cleaner 6.75 oz]] so that you can keep all the \\"gunk\\" off of it and keep it sanitized.

  870. I used this product to shave my head for over a year now. I'll agree with most the reviews here that it sheds a bit in the beginning. I was just about ready to throw it in the trash when it decided to stop.<br /><br />This is my only shave brush so I can't give you a comparison. What I will say is that I don't like applying shaving cream or any shave lubricator without a brush now. Feels too messy now that I've been using a brush for so long.<br /><br />I was using shave soap but have since switched to shampoo with my shave brush and I have literally shaved off 15 minutes of my groom time. Here are a list of my pros and cons of the brush.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Great applicator<br />Keeps hands clean(er)<br />Ornamental addition to your shave collection<br /><br />Cons:<br />Shedding<br /><br />*Shampoo technique--same as using shaving soap. I place a small amount in my shaving bowl, foam and apply. For shaving my head, I leave the bowl not too thick of foam and do the most of the foaming part on my head which keeps the foam wet longer and also exfoliates. Foaming with shampoo also has the hairs all sink to the bottom so I can rinse my hands or razor without parting the sea of floating gunk. Furthermore, my razor doesn't clog up as much and rinses out with only 2-3 swishes--no tap required. Shave soap required 4-5x more plus tapping on sink.

  872. I will start by saying that this is my first and only shaving brush and I do not profess to be a shaving guru. I am just a regular guy who is forced to shave almost every day.   887. Pros:<br />1) It's badger hair! Most genuine badger hair brushes start at twice this price and go up from there.<br />2) I've had it for about a year and a half and it's still going strong--still thick, full, and soft.<br />3) Makes a great lather--beats the old boar-hair brush I used to have hands down.<br /><br />Cons:<br />1) At this price, none<br /><br />Ok so it's not silvertip, the handle is basic boring wood, and the badger hair is the cheapest you can find. Still though, I'd buy it again in a heartbeat if I needed another, but my first one is still going strong.<br /><br />Note: some people have trouble with the bristles falling out. First, it's natural for any badger hair brush to shed a little here and there--especially for the first couple of months. If you're losing lots of bristles and the brush is becoming noticeably thinner it's probably because you're storing it wrong. EVERY badger hair brush must be carefully rinsed and shaken out after use, and hung to dry with the bristles facing DOWN. This means you need a stand for it. Buy one or make one. It doesn't have to be fancy. I used some old wire to form a little stand. If you store a genuine hair brush by setting it on the counter with the bristles up, you allow all the moisture to settle into the epoxy plug that holds the bristles to the handle. Over time this will destroy the epoxy, and the bristles will fall out. Also if you live in a humid place storing it improperly will allow mold to grow in the bristles since they can't dry out correctly. That's gross.<br /><br />This is a great little brush if it's treated right, and I expect to get several more years of use out of it. For the price it's at, it can't be beat.
  888. I have owned far more expensive brushes. Some were better and some not so. Tweezerman is unbeatable for the price and as good as many much more expensive brushes. I bought this one for my son who is just starting to shave properly.
  889. I've used this for around 6 months now and I am pleased with it. Its priced low for a quality badger brush. It has the funky smell when you get it (they all do) and it eventually goes away. The only complaint I have is that it sheds at least a couple hairs each time I use it...I dont know if its normal or not, and i do store it bristles down. Great product for price.

  917. This thing has a funky smell to it, I used it once and then tossed it in the trash. I felt like I just wiped a wet dog across my face. I hate to give bad rating because it seemed to be good quality when it came to construction and materials but it stinks bad, maybe I got a bad one but it wasn't worth it.
  918. This is a great brush to start out with, or as a travel brush, as it has a reasonable cost. Mine shed for the first few shaves then stopped. I've purchased another brush and moved this to my travel brush.
  919. I know that this is on the lower end of the badger-hair brushes and that some of the other reviews of the brush have been great, but I wasn't impressed at all. The brush shed at least 20 hairs, if not more, the first time I used it. Since then the amount has gone down with each shaving, but it is at about 2-3 per shaving. It's like a cheap paintbrush that is constantly losing its bristles, which end up on the soap cake or plastered to the side of my face. It's possible I just received the one bad brush out of the batch, but I will be looking for a better brush very soon.
  920. I'll agree with other reviews that said this brush sheds a bit. But it seemed worst to me the first shave, after a while it died down. Seems like a fine starter brush, I have no standard for comparison - but it's working fine for me with Colonel Conk's shaving soap.<br /><br />This is the cheapest you're gonna find a badger hair brush.
  921. I have been using Tweezerman products for a very long time. For the price, this brush is very nice quality. I have been using it for sometime now and have seen no evidence of bristle loss. I expect that this like other Tweezerman products will last a very long time.
  922. I've been wet shaving since 2009 and I've always wanted a badger brush (only used a Vander Hagen boar) but they are really expensive.<br /><br />Bought this one for about $12 and it's been pretty nice so far. No complaints. Good brush.
  923. This brush works very well for both creams, and soaps. I've had mine well over a year now, and can count the number of lost bristles on one hand. Fantastic product!<br /><br />What are you waiting for? Just buy it already!
  924. I am comparing this to LeisureGuy's recommended Eco tools kabuki brush. I like the feel of the badger hair on my face more than the synthetic bristles the Eco tools brush has. However, the Eco tools brush builds lather like no other I have tried. Overall, this brush feels great on my face but the lathering ability isn't too impressive.
  925. On first use, brush hairs fell out all over the place, all over the soap, all over my face, all over the razor. Completely unacceptable, there is no way this should happen with normal treatment on first use. No matter how gently you treat it, this brush sheds like crazy. A complete waste of $15. I am hoping that further use will \\"break it in\\", but I seriously doubt it.<br /><br />Update: After 10 months I am still using this brush, so maybe it was worth the 15 bucks. Hairs still fall out of it, but I did use hair conditioner on it two or three times to try to soften it up. Needs to be treated gently but workable if you don't mind the occasional hair stuck to your soapy face.
  926. I usually go to the local Barbershop for a cut, shave, and shine every week. Easy to use, a breeze to clean and leaves a smooth lather across my face. My barber doesn't like that I am not coming in frequently but my budget loves it.
  927. 100% Badger hair - excellent value. Lathers and applies the soap nicely. The brush cleans up well and we have not had excessive bristle loss. Would order again.
  928. This is a soft brush, especially compared to boar bristle brushes. They hardly ever interfere with the shave, however, so it's worth the money for what's out there.

  937. Excellent. I have used this for more than two years without issue. You need to be careful and after every use, wash it, eliminate all water pressing with two fingers and put it in a stand with the handle on top. If you put it to dry standing in the handle, it will start loosing the hairs.
  938. Works for me, no issues here
  939. Sorta stinky at first, but dish soap helps that. Little bit prickly overall. Definitely shedding more than any brush I've owned. That being said, it's a solid starter badger, and I'm going to get my use out of it. My boars were a bit to large and stiff to agree with an Arko face lather, and this brush does that job quite well. UPDATE: I was impatient with my boar brushes. They've broken in and are way better for face lathering now. So where does that leave the Tweezerman? Well, it's just a small, floppy, prickly brush that I hardly ever use, and it wasn't much cheaper than any of my boar brushes. Best case scenario: it ends up in my travel kit. The best bang for your buck in shave brushes lies in boar brushes, probably Omega and Semogue. If you specifically desire a badger hair brush and want a great value, look up a company called Whipped Dog.
  940. The wood handle fell apart after a couple years. I'm trying a plastic one that shouldn't deteriorate as easily this time around.

  943. This is the first badger I have owned but I am very happy with the quality for the price.
  944. Just started shaving with a DE and this is my first brush. So far, I'm really happy with the brush and with DE shaving overall. I knew from research that all shave brushes shed to some extent. So when I first got it I practiced making lather a few times and made sure to look for and pull any loose hairs when I cleaned it and then I do the same after each shave. If I've lathered and cleaned the brush maybe a dozen time, I've never had more than few hairs come out each time and I've never had any hair in my lather or on my face. I didn't notice much of any smell when it was new, but after a few uses it only smells like whatever shaving creme soap I used last. I do find it to be just a little rough feeling on my face when lathering, but that may just be because it's new and needs to be broken in or because it's inexpensive with lower grade badger hair. I would definitely recommend it to anyone as a great, affordable starter badger brush.
  945.   946. I have used this brush twice now and I am impressed overall. The badger hair is very nice and the brush is well formed and dense. The wooden handle is a little on the small size but not so much so. The wood is heavily lacquered (or covered in polyurethane), which seals it from water but I would think long term this finish may eventually succumb to water damage (if the wood cracks). I think however this would take a long time, especially since I always dry the handle after I am done rinsing it. I have been using a boars hair brush and I find that the badger hair takes a slightly different approach in terms of lather build up and application to the face but neither is bad or better. Many people seem to complain about the coarseness of boars hair but I found this badger hair to feel almost the same as my boars hair brush which has been in use for many years and is now rather soft. I would like to mention that the first time I used this badger hair brush it shed a lot of hair but by the second time it did not lose any so it seems to be fine now. Overall I think this is an excellent brush for the price and a great value. I could not see the need to spend $60-$80 or more for a premium brush when this one works so well.
  947. Is fun to use, and works well. I am starting to make my own soap, and that includes shaving soap.

  949. I've been using this brush about once or twice a week for about two years now.<br /><br />For those who are having issues with your brushes loosing a lot of hairs, one or two here and there is to be expected. You really shouldn't be touching the bristles except for the very base to close the bulb a little bit as your whip up your lather.<br /><br />The bristles are stiff enough to make a good lather, but soft enough to feel quite nice against the face.<br /><br />Also, make sure you let this guy dry with the bristles hanging down, otherwise the water gets into the base and starts to crack the wood.<br /><br />If you take good care of it, it will reward you with close shaves for a long time.
  950. This brush is very nice for the price. Some hairs fall out of the brush the first time it is used, but they fall out less and less the more it is used. I've been using one as my travel brush for nine years now, and it's still going strong. The wooden handle has not cracked or split. When put to use with a good-quality soap it produces a thick, rich lather that my straight razor seems to love.<br /><br />This would make a good starter or travel brush, or a regular brush for a shaver on a budget.

  993. I have been using this brush for the past two years. In the entire time I've been using this brush, I've lost maybe 15-30 bristles, but in all honesty I'd have been surprised if I didn't.<br /><br />Quite simply, this brush beats every other brush on the market in price, and it still performs the basic functions of a brush without fail!<br /><br />No, this little guy won't be winning any awards for quality, but if you are looking for a starter brush for wet-shaving (as I was two years ago), this is the ONLY brush I'd suggest. No beginner shaver has the know-how to choose the right brush for them, nor should they invest the 50-400 dollars for the higher end brushes.<br /><br />As a side-note: I don't treat this brush well. I dry it while it's standing on it's wooden handle, and I don't pay it even the slightest bit of care, yet it hasn't given up on me.<br /><br />You cannot go wrong with this brush unless you are looking for a specific feature only available in higher-end brushes like higher hair-count, thicker bristles, different materials, or size.   1003. My name is Donovan and I am new to wet shaving although I have been using a cheap walmart synthetic for the past year now with shaving soap and a cartridge razor till I could afford the real thing.<br /><br />I always hated shaving, it was a pain, the razor always pulled and tugged and I always bled after. I thought this was how shaving was supposed to be, I jumped from electric to razor to electric and back again, sinking 1000's into it and never enjoying it all. I then heard about wet shaving from news I was reading and started to research it. I found some how to vids on youtube and they really showed and explained just how great and painless it is to use this type of razor. I researched the heck out of this new way of shaving and realized two things, 1. this type is way to awesome and takes me back to the way people are meant to shave, and 2. this type is rather expensive but price wont stop me. Now price did stop me for the longest time, no job and all but I still want to do this so i have bought everything i need piece by piece. I also have to say it is really hard to find a badger hair brush that is good quality and yet cheaper and on top of that willing to actually ship to Canada.<br /><br />(To all Canadian customers like myself, do not order from american wholesale, they will rook you out of your money, they do not provide you with a tracking number and they will not return your emails when the product is late, order from amazon.com and they will treat you right.)<br /><br />Now onto this brush. I ordered this brush because it is 100% badger hair, it is well made and the handle is wood which is really important to me as I appreciate fine crafted wood products. This brush is the pinacle of great craftmenship, oh and dont go by the picture it is actually a darker wood finish with a copper ring which looks real nice for this brush, and tips of the bristles have a silver color to them. The brush is priced the same as a cheap walmart synthetic and this brush isso amazing for shaving. People say that wet shaving with either a DE razor or a straight razor is an art form and they really want to shave again, these people are not crazy, they are completely right and with this brush there is no exception to this, I cant wait till the next time, so that i may use this brush again. Please people buy this brush and take care of it properly, it really will last you a very long time.<br /><br />As for care instructions there is a review under the 5 stars that will tell you what you need to do to make sure the brush stays pristine for many many years.<br /><br />Thank you.
  1004. [[VIDEOID:mo3RZJAPCUPQJCN]]I like these little brushes. I have been using them for many years and they work well for me.<br /><br />♦ Quality is good.   1005. The Tweezerman was my first shaving brush. I was getting started with DE shaving and I didn't want to spend a ton of money, since I wasn't sure if I would stick with it. Initially it shed quite a few hairs (10-20 per use), but after a couple weeks of use and shaking out the loose hairs from manufacturing, the shedding stopped.<br /><br />While this brush was adequate and lathered ok, it felt cheap. The handle feels very light, and the knot is not particularly dense, so it doesn't hold as much water. In the end I ended up buying and Omega Pure Badger brush that is a little larger, and much denser, and lathers much better than the Tweezerman. Of course it also cost more than twice what I paid for this brush.<br /><br />Where I do think the Tweezerman brush has value is as a travel brush. It's relatively compact, and it's inexpensive enough that loss or damage isn't a huge concern.<br /><br />Pro:<br />Inexpensive<br />Compact<br />Did I mention inexpensive?<br /><br />Con:<br />Feels cheap<br />Sparse knot<br /><br />Who I recommend this brush for: Beginners on a budget, travelers looking for a compact inexpensive solution, cheap-skates who can put up with the less than stellar performance.
  1006. it's been hard to find a good shaving brush. This brush is the best one I've seen, and very cheap! thanks
  1007. This brush is serviceable. I can soap it up and get the soap to my face with it. The quills are noticeably sharp which is a problem with less expensive brushes, but they don't fall out which is another problem with some less expensive ones. I had left my brush of many years behind at a hotel and was in a hurry to get a replacement -- it's the only way I've shaved for many years. Delivery on this one was fast, and I'm still using it. One can never be sure ordering another more expensive one online that it, too, won't have sharp quills *sigh*
  1008. My brush just arrived, it was exactly as represented and the quality is superior to others I looked at that were more expensive. I recommend this brush!
  1009. Good value for a Badger brush. Work well and spreads lather as good as other brushes costing twice as much.
  1010. Not the best brush on the market. It is prickly and loses bristles fairly quick, but because of the fact that it really is 100% badger hair and because of the price it is a good brush for beginning wetshavers.
  1011. I enjoy using this...it saves shaving cream and is also neater. I recommend the young guys to check it out.
  1012. This shaving brush is perhaps the most inexpensive way to get a pure Badger bristle shaving brush. I've now been using it for over four years, and it has not shed any great quantity of its bristles like the cheaper brushes on the market. The brush head remains densely packed and quite soft. Hopefully, it will remain that way for some time to come. In the meantime, I do enjoy the close and comfortable shaves that are aided by this brush. Because of it, I have sworn off of canned shave gels for every situation except travel. They just can't compare to your average $1.50 cake of shaving soap and this brush. This was a very worthwhile purchase for me.
  1013. I was a bit disappointed with this product at first as the hairs were falling off the first few times that I used it. However, after awhile, those initial lose hairs were gone and the product worked flawlessly. I think it is a good brush for the price after you get a few lose hairs out.
  1014. Have owned my original Tweezerman for 5 years. Love it--great brush. Owned the second one I bought as a travel brush for 3 weeks before the knot popped out. Maybe issues with quality control?   1017. This thing really stinks. Not only do the hairs shed like cray cray, but the brush smells like the hair was harvested from the perianal region of the badger. I would have imagined that they would have a process to eliminate or at the very least minimize that smell of a wet dog in heat that just hangs on this brush.<br /><br />Honestly, this thing smells like it was being stored in a hobo's holey underpants during the summertime.<br /><br />It smells like a 300 pound man was using it for years to apply talcum powder to his groin.<br /><br />It smells like wet flatulence in a summertime car with the windows rolled up.<br /><br />Oh yes, before I forget, the little chrome stand they try to peddle with this brush is too short to hold it off any flat surface. Serious disappointment folks.
  1018. After a few weeks, the handle casing got loose and fell off. I still use it though because the handle is plenty long, it just looks ugly. The bristles are good, but to be fair, it's the first shaving brush I've ever tried. I probably won't try this one again, but it's decent.
  1019. the only problem I had with this brush was that the badger smell lasted a decent amount of time. 8 or so months later and it's just a small hint of the smell. now it smells a ton more like my almond soap than the badger.   1060. No problem with this. I read the other reviews and agree with them. For the price this is as expected.
  1061. I have had this brush for nearly two years now, and it has performed within expected parameters. The bristles are a bit rough and coarse on the skin, but this can be greatly mitigated by angling the brush as you apply lather.<br /><br />During the month, it would shed a few bristles; this is expected with any badger brush, and not a complaint. At a price that's quite difficult to beat, you get what you pay for- and then some. This brush is still going strong! No unpleasant odors, no falling apart, or other issues I've seen reported in these reviews.<br /><br />Like other reviews addressed, proper care of this (any, and all) brushes is paramount to the survivability of said brush. To care for the brush, in a nut shell, you need to shake out as much water as you can when you finish shaving (flicking of the wrist does this nicely), then hang it upside down; with the flat base pointing up. It may be tempting to let it dry on the base, but this will ruin the brush. You can either purchase a stand for your brush and/or razor, or build a makeshift one to let it hang.<br /><br />In summary, decent brush at an excellent value. Rather coarse bristles, but this helps with exfoliating your skin during the shave, and can be &#34;adjusted&#34; by the angle you apply it with.
  1062. I read most of the negative reviews, but had already ordered it as only 2 were left and the price had dropped.....WOW ... I'm glad I got it. A little scented shave cream/soap took away the mild scent and it has not been shedding. I looked at the dates of the negative reviews and I'm guessing that there was a bad batch of fur during that time last year. I smelled it out of the box...very mild. I smelled it after wetting...stronger smell like wife's hair after playing tennis...Shampooed with Panteen... pretty neutral smell. Used it with Old Spice shave cream, rinsed, dryed....it smells nice. Glad I saved that money so I can take my wife to dinner after my shave.
  1063. Great shaving brush. Sooooo soft. Should have bought one of these first time around.
  1064. Having used this brush several times now, I have experienced no lost hairs or other problems some reviewers note. I wonder if it might be the lessons my Grandfather taught me.<br /><br />He insisted that a brush be soaked, bristles down, in a cup of warm water for a minute or two before lathering. The water should only cover about half of the length of the bristles. Natural wicking action of the hairs will take care of the rest.<br /><br />Upon removing it from the soak, two shakes over the sink removes the excess water before lathering. Immediately when lathering is finished, the brush is returned to the soak until shaving is done.<br /><br />I always rinse the brush from the side, rotating it slowly under running water until all soap is gone. Two quick shakes removes all of the excess water and -- here's the trick for many, I think -- the brush is stored hanging bristles down until the next use. Though it has a flat, stand-up base, that should only ever be used temporarily while lathering or when the bristles have fully dried.<br /><br />Great value. Great little brush. I shave my neck and head with it every day and love it.
  1065. This shave brush has held up really well over the past year and I have a lot of confidence that it will continue to for a good while longer. Great price for a great product.
  1066. Still works great, and travels well. Shed a few hairs at the start of use and a little though out its use, but has retained its shape.
  1067. This is a seriously overlooked brush. This was my first shaving brush, and I've been using it exclusively for three years straight now. It sheds a hair or two once in a while, but otherwise, it's become quite soft. There are brushes that cost hundreds of dollars, and then there's the overlooked Tweezerman for $12.00. It's not as soft as the high-end brushes, but it exfoliates well and raises the hairs on the neck better than many softer (i.e. silver tip) brushes. This thing is bulletproof.
  1068. I didn't realize how small this brush really was until I got it. I had been using a the one in the Van der Hagen box (from HEB), which is a boar hair brush. However, despite the size difference, the Tweezerman brush lathered easily twice as fast as the boar hair brush and felt noticeably softer against my skin. Also, this brush retains water for a VERY long time (still fairly wet after being at work for 9 hours), so extra care should be taken to ensure that it's as dry as you can get it prior to hanging it UPSIDE DOWN. You don't want your brand new brush to mildew, after all.<br /><br />Above all, this initial review is a positive one. The brush is both cheap and superior to others in it's price range. All I would change is to have half again as many bristles... maybe even twice as many if you're a large fellow. Then again, it lathers so fast and goes on so smoothly, it may not be necessary.<br /><br />Highly recommended for a first timer.

  1089. I got this shaving brush off of Amazon for my husband in January 2013 (on my separate account). He has been using it regularly since then, and for a while I used it as well. Then at a small, local thrift store, I found a new, sealed in plastic shaving brush. It had no brand name on the plastic seal or on the handle. The thrift store had a couple of them. It has a solid wooden base, and I have no idea what type of hair it consists of. I paid a whopping 50 cents for it. When I first used it, I realized how much this Tweezerman sucks in comparison. I wish I had gone back to buy the other no-name brand version at the thrift store at that time!<br /><br />Every time we use the Tweezerman, it sheds. Before purchasing any of our shaving equipment, I did a lot of reading on Reddit, so I do know that you must hold the base in your hand and use your fingers to hold together the bristles as your work your lather. In spite of this, it sheds. I just grabbed it for this review, and I can sit here and pull out hairs probably all night long. When I lathered my legs for shaving, it would leave stray hairs on me, which would then clog the razor if I did not pick them off before shaving. It was just a hassle all around. On the other hand, my no-name brand lucky thrift store find does not shed a single hair.<br /><br />Aside from the shedding, the no-name brand forms a better lather than the Tweezerman, and it also seems to lift the hairs on my legs better before shaving. It seems to have a better structure to it, too. The bristles do not bend or flare out as much as the Tweezerman For some reason, my husband continues to use the Tweezerman; it may be a case of His vs. Hers, and it can also be because he says he doesn't like &#34;change&#34;. Apparently the shedding is not a deal breaker to him every morning. Regardless, I plan on replacing this for him with a better brand.

  1094. I started out shaving with a safety razor in December. My wife filled my Christmas list with the Merkur 180 razor and a Van Der Hagen Shaving Soap kit, which includes a bowl, boar brush and cup. I asked for the kit, thinking there couldn't be that much of a difference between brushes. I was wrong.<br /><br />The boar brush in the kit is adequate, but I couldn't get a good soap &#34;whip&#34; consistently. I would get a flat soap covering, rather than a nice, thick coating. Using the boar brush on your face is like buying a throw-away paint brush to paint your house. It will work, but the results will not be the best.<br /><br />After I received my Tweezerman brush, I could get a good soap whip, allowing for better soap coverage on my face. This lets me get a much more consistent shave. The badger hair also gives a more defoliating effect, softening skin after the shave.<br /><br />For the first few days of use, there were several hairs that shed from the brush. Based upon the other reviews, this is normal and has stopped.<br /><br />I'm sure that if you spent more money, you could get a better brush. For the money, this is a great badger brush that is much better than a boar brush.
  1095. I knew it would have a smell so no point in taking a star away. Lathers up soap real well and applies real well. Did see a few hairs come out but that's the nature of the beast. Would buy again.

  1100. Don't be mistaken, there are better brushes out there. But to find a better brush for the money you will be hard pressed (the Frank's Shaving line will beat it for a bit more money). 5 Stars for value vs. quality.<br /><br />This is my daily and travel brush and has been for several months now. I was a bit alarmed at the number of hairs it lost the first week. This quickly cured itself, and has lost a rare hair perhaps once a week after it broke in. I regularly shampoo and condition the brush as I do all my brushes to promote long life. It still dries to a nice full bloom and quickly whips up a nice lather with any soap I choose be it cream or puck. Using a scuttle or face lathering as I do on the trips, it performs very well.<br /><br />For a luxury weekend shave I have other brushes that will outperform this one. For someone new to wet shaving, or for an old timer like me that wants a nice everyday shave, it will find a place in your rotation.

  1104. This was my first shave brush. I bought it on 11/1/2012. I initially loved the price point and i had read that after a few shaves it would most likely stop shedding. That never happened. This brush shed at least 10 hairs per shave, every shave. It got to the point that when I would shake the water out of the brush that a few hairs would fall out. I took excellent care of the brush making sure to dry it in a brush holder and to never leave any soap in it. Today as I was shaking the water out of the brush for a shave the knot flew right out of the handle. Good thing I have a backup brush. What a piece of garbage this brush is.
  1105. I have been usin this brush for just over two yard now with good results. The brush has held up well and basically looks an feels like it did when I first bought it. It lost a hair here and there but not in any appreciable or noticeable amount, and it certainly hasn't affected the functionality of the item. It lathers up quickly and is soft and easy to clean. What more could you ask for?

  1107. This is my first shaving brush and it still does the job after a year and a half of use. I initially would lose the occasional hair from the brush early on through several shaves, but it's pretty rare now--perhaps it simply needs a \\"break-in\\" period. I actually get better lathers now than when I first got it.<br /><br />Obviously there are better brushes out there for more money, and I knocked off a star due to that difference in feel. But if you're just getting started in DE shaving or simply want to save a few bucks, this is a great purchase that can be used at home or for travel.

  1109. Keep in mind this is just one guys experience with the brush and there are many reviews that love the brush.<br />I just don't like the brush. I have several other brushes I like much better. The bristles on my brush are stiff and felt like small needles sticking in your face when working in the shaving soap. My face burned for 3 days after using this brush. The only thing I had changed in my normal daily shaving was the brush. The brush smelled like a dead animal when it arrived. I cleaned the brush and even put conditioner on it trying to kill the smell and soften it up a bit. I have put this brush back on it's hanger and went back to using my Frank Shaving Brush, much softer and holds a ton of soap.<br />I say this again this is just my personal experience with the brush and I haven't had this problem with any of my other brushes.<br /><br />This is a follow up from my first review and thought i would try the brush out again a few weeks later. I have found that the hairs are continually falling out, stuck in my shaving soap and getting stuck to my face and in my razor. To me this is just a poor quality brush or I just got a crap brush.   1111. I purchased the Tweezerman Shaving Brush to go along with my new Edwin Jagger safety razor. The badger hairs are glued to the stand and hold a good amount of water when used. I don't have any other experience with shaving brushes, but I am guessing that this brush is probably on the rough side (you get what you pay for). Overall, I have enjoyed the wet shaving experience and the Tweezerman brush is a pleasant part of the overall experience. Having said that, I am sure that I will eventually want a more expensive, softer shaving brush.<br /><br />In the meantime, I will continue to use the Tweezerman brush. It seems to get a little softer with each use. It shed quite a bit of hair at the beginning, and that is tapering off somewhat. Again, there are some drawbacks to this brush, but, overall, I don't regret getting it. It does its job reasonably well. I knew that it wasn't a luxurious brush when I bought it and that is precisely what I got.

  1116. After searching for a badger brush to enter my safety-razor-shaving switchover, I decided to give this one a try, solely because it's a badger brush, yet a fraction of the price of other shaving brushes. In fact, I passed over this brush several times BECAUSE OF THE PRICE, thinking that it COULDN'T POSSIBLY be a badger brush for that price... and yet, it seems to be, as far as I can tell, based on my lather and wear so far. I finally ordered it figuring \\"what have I got to lose for the price?\\"-- and I'm glad I did.<br /><br />As others have mentioned, I've also had an issue with a few bristles falling out during my first few shaves. They work their way out of the cluster and get washed away during my rinse. Honestly, I can't even tell they're gone-- the brush has only gotten better for me the more I use it.   1117. I'm losing about 5 hairs exactly with every shave as well! I thought it would slow down after the first couple weeks but continues to lose 3-6 hairs every shave. Yes people, I treat it gently, yes it dries hanging, etc. Doesn't matter. Pain in the ass. I think just as with any other cheap product the intent is great, but quality control often suffers. Quality control is difficult in the first place when you're using the fur from an animal, but multiply that by the probably 100,000 of these Tweezerman made and it's easy to understand why this can happen.<br /><br />The bright side is the cheap price, essentially the badger experience, minus the longevity. I accidentally added two to my cart, but it'll probably take another year for this thing to \\"go bald\\". I just don't like having long hairs in my shave mug, or on my face! Only thing I can say about this brush is to rub it back and forth on your fingers before shaving, when it's dry from hanging, those hairs will fall off that loosened while drying, before they get into your mug.<br /><br />I rated 3* because I would've rather paid more for one that didn't shed, than have to buy one that does, and then a new one in the future. A good badger brush can last for a decade or more, I don't expect this one to last more than a year with proper treatment and shaving every other day.

Brush the soap until the bubbles in the lather being formed at microscopic, then bring brush to you (wet, washed) beard and work the lather up and into your stubble.   1130. I tried a cheap Jaguar shaving brush that had plastic like bristles that only lasted a few months. Pay the few extra bucks for this Tweezerman! I've since moved up to an expensive Art of shaving brush but its not THAT much better- it is bigger and stiffer than this one though.<br /><br />SHAVING- let me save you years of trial and error: take a warm shower & wash your face with billy jealousy exfoliating facial cleanser, shave afterwards with a $50 Merkur safety razor handle with good blades (save $100's on mach 3 refills!), use a $20 Tweezerman badger hair shaving brush to apply taylor of old street bond (or proraso) shaving cream (you can let it set in a minute), shave WITH the grain DOWN, SLOWLY, SOFTLY (don't press hard- let the weight of the handle and sharp blade do the cutting), lastly rub on a fingertip of proraso pre/post shave cream while your face is still wet and let it dry! Say goodbye to razor bumps and ingrown hairs FOREVER! Trust me- I've tried dozens of pricey face washes, shaving creams, and after shaves over the last 4 years. If you don't want to commit so much money yet- order the pre/post shave proraso cream online, buy proraso shave cream online or at bath and body works (under their C.O. Bigelow label) then get the cheap single blade disposables (mach 3's are too aggressive) at a grocery store and you'll notice a difference overnight.
  1131. This shaving brush is the bomb. It simply breaks in very easy, gathers the shave soap onto the bristles wonderfully and holds up like new over the years. I purchased a second shave brush “just in case” however the first brush is working perfectly fine. Simply make sure you allow the bristles to dry by laying the brush flat or using a holder with the bristles pointing downward. You can t go wrong with the Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush .

  1141. I recently got tired of the ridiculous expense of shaving with the major razor brands like Gillette and Schick, so I made the switch to the more traditional safety razor method with cream and a brush. I wasn't really sure if I'd like this method, so I tried to keep the initial costs on the accessories (like this brush) as low as possible. As it turns out, I love this shaving style and would never go back to the overpriced junk razors sold in stores.<br /><br />Overall, I can't complain too much for the price. It is Badger hair brush and doesn't feel too coarse on the face, but the old adage &#34;you get what you pay for&#34; really does come into play with this product. Like I said, the product is Badger hair, but you can tell this brush is not made from the softer fur of the animal (i.e. the 'silvertip' neck hairs) like some of the more expensive brushes available. There are definitely multiple grades of quality with these brushes, with this one being firmly in the lowest grade.<br /><br />It does have issues with fraying and shedding. I usually lose a couple hairs with each shave, and the outside strands have trouble re-forming with the rest of the brush. And, yes, to anyone who may comment on this statement, I am aware of the proper care procedure, and I do not leave the brush sitting on its handle to dry.<br /><br />Overall, this is great for someone looking to experiment with this style of shaving (like I was) and not wanting to spend 50-60 dollars on a high quality silvertip shaving brush or for someone who's okay with planned obsolescence and is willing to replace it every few months with a new one. Personally, this brush has served its purpose for me in getting me started with this shaving style, and I will probably get a better quality brush very soon.
  1142. Very nice and it got here when they said.
  1143. This is one of the best purchases I have ever made. It's rare that you get great quality and a low price in a product nowadays.<br /><br />I got the idea of a shaving brush from a store dedicated entirely to shaving in a high-end shopping center in San Francisco. Of course, their shaving brushes started at $35 and the high end was $70 which I though was pretty high. Imagine my surprise when I saw it on Amazon for $8 when I first started using it two years ago. I have now purchased a second brush to keep in my travel kit as I forgot it on our last trip and really missed the great shave a full head of lather provides.<br /><br />I had switched to all natural hair and skin products about two years previously and was using Weleda shaving cream after using a gel silicone type preparation for many years that was loaded with chemicals. (I have no connection to the Weleda company and provide this only as information for those who want to research organic products.) I had been spreading the cream around on my face with my fingertips but was unable to work up a satisfactory lather. This brush works unbelievably!<br /><br />Here are the pros and cons:<br /><br />Pros: 1. Very inexpensive.<br /> 2. My original brush is still in excellent condition after two years of daily use.<br /><br />Cons: 1. Yes, there is an odor when you first start using it. It is badger hair after all; but it will go away after a short time.<br /> 2. Some of the bristles will come out with each use but this will also stop after a period of time. Just be patient.<br /><br />Some tips: As with some reviewers, I have found that some minimal care is required to get the best use of this brush.<br /> 1. Always rinse the brush under warm running water after each use.<br /> 2. Gently compress the brush sideways to expel as much water as you can from the brush.<br /> 3. Never dry the brush standing up on its base. I lay the brush on its side in a small 3 X 4&#34; plastic kitchen storage container with no lid on and a folded-up piece of paper towel in the bottom that I change every two weeks to prevent bacteria growth. You can alternatively purchase a brush holder stand and use that.<br /><br />Don't be afraid to give it a try. If you enjoy a clean, comfortable shave, this is the brush to get.

I clean it after use, hold it at the knot when using it, dry it with the bristles down and follow the guidance found here in other reviews. But my brush sheds a bristle or two each use. That being said, I would buy this brush again in a second. It has very good quality bristles, soft and full. For a beginners brush, it meets or exceeds all expectations. I would recommend it.

  1152. I've seen a lot of poor ratings for this product, but I have to say with proper care, its a great brush. I will attempt to address the problems several have commented on from my experience with this brush.<br /><br />Shedding: Yes, brushes do shed, especially if they're under $20. I simply soaked the brush and combed out all the loose hairs. No more shedding after that and I've had the brush well over a month now.<br /><br />Odor: My brush did have a slight &#34;wet animal&#34; odor. I shampooed the brush with a coconut scented shampoo my wife uses. I left the lather on for about an hour before rinsing it very well. That took care of the odor.<br /><br />I also hang my brush to dry with the knot hanging down. This is the proper way to store your brush. Also, when you shake water out of your brush, hold the retaining ring with the tips of your fingers with the handle resting in your palm.<br /><br />I've had the brush for over a month now and I'm very pleased with it. I like a coarser-haired brush that really exfoliates the skin. This brush serves that purpose very well and produces a very nice lather. I make my own soap using an African black soap based shaving butter melted and mixed well with a basic soap natural soap base.<br /><br />Over all, I am very pleased with this brush. Shipping was fast and the price was extremely affordable. Overpaying for a brush just doesn't make sense to me and this brush is fully capable of being used everyday when properly cared for. This is a very good brush to purchase and I highly recommend it. Once its broken in, its a great brush.

  1167. This was my first shaving brush, and I've gotten quite hooked on shaving this way now and can't quite imagine returning to the days of using big spray cans of Gillette shaving gel. I've been using this brush almost daily for coming up on two years now (purchased Nov. 2012 from Amazon), so this is a review from a long-use perspective. There was a period where it shed a noticeable number of bristles -- 1 to 3 lost on a near-daily basis over a couple of weeks' time -- I can assume this was just some spots where the adhesive wasn't good or something. Once that period of shedding was over, it's been fine. Rarely loses a bristle (perhaps once a month?) and it never lost so many as to really impact the density. Despite best-use and proper storage techniques, the wooden handle cracked slightly a few months in, so I used some clear epoxy-type glue to just fill it in. This too has never been a problem since. So yes, there were a couple of issues, and I don't know if they're endemic to this product across its production or if I just got a bad one, but apart from these two problems, I've been really pleased with the brush, particularly given its entry-level price point. After the initial problems and just under a year after buying the Tweezerman, I bought another brand &#34;pre-emptively,&#34; kind of anticipating the imminent failure of the Tweezerman. That subsequent purchase is actually still new in its box, sitting in my closet. Maybe one day, I'll relegate the Tweezerman to &#34;travel shaving brush&#34; status and break out the new one, but for now, nearly two years on, it's still doing the job admirably.
  1168. Easy to use, and feels good when you put the lather on your face. The brush feels like it will last a long time. I know another person that used this product, and he recommended it to me. I thought I needed a more expensive brush but this works just fine.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Inexpensive<br />Lathers the cream easily<br /><br />Cons:<br />None (after a week of using this product)
  1169. I have had this for 3 years, now. It is a great brush for a low price. It was a soothing upgrade from my boar brush. It has lost very little bristles over the time.<br /><br />Get it now. It comes highly recommended. Especially if you're just starting out. You can test out how you enjoy wet shaving with a quality brush on a budget.
  1170. Excellent first brush, I had it for a year until I lost my stand, stopped taking care of it, and it broke. It's all my fault though, and I've since bought two more of these for friends.<br /><br />Make sure you buy a stand. As other commenters mention, if it's wet when you leave it in the position in the picture (standing on the base), eventually it will crack and break.<br /><br />You have to wash it out, flick it a couple times to get rid of water, and then put it in a stand where it can drip dry.
  1171. I liked the brush. It is working very well for me. I think it is loosing to many hair too fast. But I like it.
  1172. I bought it as a gift, and will give it for fathers day as part of a set I am putting together.
  1173. The brush is well constructed, decently priced and work well ... However, it has a funny smell to it when wet. What the hell is that? I am going to see if the odor goes away with time,. ... Other wise the brush will go away (back to it's seller).<br /><br />Pag<br /><br />Update 7/13/2014<br /><br />I was unreasonable and hard on the Tweezerman shaving brush. The smell is gone. The brush works well and is one of my favorite among the 5 I rotate and use. It is soft, holds a lot of lather and is well constructed. It does not lose any bristles either. It strongly resembles my Escali brush. Only it is larger and fuller. I would recommend this brush to anyone who wants a nice shaving brush at a decent price.<br /><br />Regards, D. Paganelli
  1174. I tried this brush based on a recommendation from reddit.com/r/wickededge, and I'm glad I did. I'm fairly new to wet shaving, and like most people I have been trying to find the sweet spot between affordability and quality. I tried a few other brushes first, but they either felt like I was wire brushing my face or else they shed like a dog in August.<br /><br />This brush feels soft but firm on the face, it lathers well, and it's been holding up well to regular use. I clean it, dry it, and hang it bristles-down after every use, so I'm hoping that it continues to work well for a long time to come.
  1175. I like this better than the other brush I've used that was not badger hair. I think it was boar hair.<br /><br />The badger hair in this brush seems a little prickly at first, but it works up a lather ten times better and spreads it on quite well. My main reason for not giving it 5 stars is that it does seem like the hairs come out rather quickly. My last brush did not last very long (maybe 9 or 10 months) and I suspect this one will be replaced a little earlier than I'd like, as well. But, for near $10, you get what you pay for, I guess.
  1176. This is my second shaving brush and I am very impressed with it. Very little bristle loss after the first couple uses and its not lost any in the past 8 uses. The price is also very reasonable for the look and quality. It has a more natural wood color than the picture would lead you to believe which is exactly why I bought it, looks great. As far as quality, I have said it before and will say it again. You cannot dry this standing up....none of these brushes are meant for that. They all use what seems to be a type of wood glue to hold it together and it will fall apart if you do this often. Do yourself a favor and hang it upside down using a brush and razor holder like it was intended. One last thing, its a bit smaller than you may be use to but after a while it will grow on you quickly. I would not trade it for another at this point in time.
  1177. I've had this brush for two years now, and it's still working well. I've only lost a few bristles on it, and it'd likely last for another few years. Be sure to store it on it's side (which I did for the first year) or using a holder, do NOT let it dry like the item picture shows.
  1178. I will start by saying this is probably the best $10 brush you can buy. Then I will say that there are A LOT of more expensive brushes, and I mean even $30 -$50 that are much better than this brush. If you are trying to go cheap to see if wet shaving is something you want to do before you invest big money, then this is an ok brush to get you started, however most who love wet shaving will say don't even bother. I used this brush to get started about a year ago and it got me to a place where I wanted to experience something different. A Thater and a Chubby 2 later, I have a small brush collection and long ago gave this brush to someone else who was interested in wet shaving.<br /><br />Moral of the story, if you are just starting, maybe go with a $50 Thater unless you really aren't sure if you will like it at all, then use this brush to give it a try.
  1179. I orginally bought this brush to use it on my cat. Her fur is usually ruffled and a total mess. Not only did it take forever to brush her due to the small size, but it didn't smooth it out at all! This product literally turned her into a feline ball of static electricity! She was shocking herself on every metal object for over an hour.<br /><br />As a licensed and highly recommended vet, I do NOT endorse this product for use on animals!
  1180. Well firstly theres nothing technical about a brush, i came across some really expensive ones like the one from art of shaving which costs 55 USD, however i went and bought this one and yes i will admit that the art of shaving badger brush is maybe a tad softer but barely and the price difference is huge, also its used to lather up the shaving cream which it does perfectly so im happy and satisfied, one less star for not being as soft but i dont want a feather rubbing on my face and falling asleep either so its ok..
  1181. This brush lives up to every review I read about it. If you will take the time to rinse it and store it as the instructions say, this brush will last a very long time. I am super pleased with it. Highly recommend.
  1182. I have purchased several of these over the years (4 or 5).<br /><br />You won't find a better badger brush with a solid wood handle.<br />More expensive silver tipped bristles may be softer but consequently won't ex-foliate or lather as quickly.<br /><br />Keep in mind that every badger's fur is NOT exactly alike.<br />Of the brushes I have used, some were softer and stinkier, but all worked reasonably well after breaking them in.<br />Some tend to loose bristles more than others, but this usually tapers off.<br /><br />Tip: TO GET THE STINK OUT<br />Work baby oil (tea tree oil works a bit better, but is more expensive) into the brush the way you would lather up soap (hold the handle--not the bristles), and work it out with generous amounts of toothpaste (baking soda & peroxide tooth paste). This will clean out and diffuse the oil-based \\"skunky\\" smell better than soap. This will also make the bristles more stiff.<br /><br />Tip: TO FIX A LOOSE KNOT<br />The first brush I purchased had a loose knot that shed bristles and eventually fell out of the handle. I glued it back in with shoe glue and never had anymore troubles. Actually, after fixing that brush it was virtually indestructible.<br /><br />Tip: TO CARE FOR YOUR BRUSH<br />The brush I treated like a delicate flower (storing upside down, gently lathering with no pumping, etc.) was the one that shed bristles & eventually fell apart. A brush held together with an adequate amount of glue will have ZERO PROBLEMS.<br />I have since learned to simply leave my brushes bristle up on the shelf in the shower. Some times I rinse the lather out (before I put it back on the shelf) and sometimes I don't (soap is a drying agent--works against rot).<br />Always rinse out the brush before use.<br />Bottom Line - if your brush has problems, fix it - there is no need to coddle it.
  1183. so I sanded the handle and painted with a wood stainer and it looks much better.<br />I've been using for a week , i cant compare it with another since is my first shaving brush.
  1184. I purchased this brush in October 2010 and have used it since then. It works well and has lost no more than a dozen bristles in two years of use. Like any shaving brush it needs to be well rinsed, dried after use and then stored hanging tip down. Treated correctly, I think this brush will last a very long time. The bristles are a little shorter than on the Parker brush I previously review, but it had no smell when new.
  1185. I think I am treating it well--drying bristles down, holding the base of the bristles to protect the knot, not overloading with water, etc.-- but the thing just keeps shedding. I know it's not a particularly high quality brush, and it does get the job done, I just don't like picking hairs off my cheeks every third day.
  1186. This is my everyday brush and it works fine. At first I did have trouble with some of the hairs falling out but stopped soaking the brush in very hot water. I think that was affecting the glue that holds the knot together. Now I just dip the brush in hot water, not deep enough to get the knot wet. I also hang it bristles down to let it dry. This stopped the loss of hairs and I've used it for 6 months now. This is definitely a great value for a badger brush so it gets top ratings for the price.
  1187. A very well made & attractive shaving brush. I've owned a few cheap shaving brushes & decided to buy an authentic badger fur type. Such as rinsing and hanging upside down to dry. Since I've been doing what this person recommended, its been working like wonders! I look forward to shaving as I've never used a brush before.   1194. I've purchased a few synthetic, pure badger hair, and combination shaving brushes within this price range over the past few years. Do not expect such quality shaving instruments to last over two years of solid use. With that said, the Tweezerman brush is far and away the superior of ten buck brushes, based on my experience and despite loosing hairs with every lather. The bristles are stiff causing a pleasant exfoliation of the skin and gentle lifting of the beard. The brush itself holds a decent amount of water and produces a lofty lather. Though finely constructed and ergonomically sized, the wooden handle almost ensures this particular brush will not last over the two year mark. This is evidenced by the previously mentioned loss of hairs during every shave. You get what you pay for and the Tweezerman is worth the money. This will be my final ten buck brush purchase, however. I've spent close to $50.00 on these types of instruments in the past five years. For that amount of money I could have purchased a very fine brush and one that will last for years and years to come.<br /><br />So my advise to anyone looking to purchase their first shaving brush or to upgrade from a different but still-usable ten buck brush: Bite the bullet and pay for a very nice $50 brush (with silver tip badger hair if you can swing the price). You'll not only save money in the long run but enjoy a much niceer quality lather and shave while it pays itself off over the years.<br /><br />If you're like me, however, and rarely have an additional fifty bucks lying around when your other ten-buck brush finally bites the dust, the Tweezerman is the best possible deal for the money. Just expect to do it again in two years.
  1195. I previously had another brand of badger-hair brush that I liked, which never smelled like a badger. Imagine spreading &#34;wet zoo-smell&#34; over your face before you shave each day. That lather is right there under your nose, tainted with the oily smell of badger. I've rinsed and squeezed multiple times and the initial smell has dropped off, but I don't think it ever will completely.<br /><br />This product was only $10, so it's not even worth the effort to return it, but I won't buy this brand again. One thing I learned in my newbie DE shaving status is that a shaving brush must be dried hanging down in order to keep it in good shape. I purchased a simple plastic stand on Amazon, which works great.

  1229. I'm new to DE shaving, and I purchased this shaving brush based on the recommendation of folks over in wicked_edge. After using it for about a week now, I'd say the brush is pretty good. The bristles are a little softer than I anticipated, so I may end up buying a boar brush just for some variation, but this works pretty well and really isn't a huge concern. The brush lathers well with my [[ASIN:B001JHEY14 Proraso Shave Soap, Sensitive, 150ml/5.2 oz (147 g) Jar]], so I'm happy. As far as bristle/hair loss goes, I haven't experienced as much as other folks who have posted reviews here. During my first two uses, I lost a few, maybe a dozen at the most. But over the past three or four uses I haven't lost any.<br /><br />The only other thing that I can add to this review involves the care of the brush. I don't want to spend $20-$25 on a stand that I don't really need, so I looked at advice on how to care for this thing. Some people complain that if you stand it on its base, water will get in and ruin the epoxy that holds the knot to the base. From what I read, one strategy is to shake the loose water off the brush, then towel dry it before standing it on its base. Since I haven't had the brush for but a week, I cannot comment on the long term effectiveness of this strategy. What I can say is that shaking it off and then drying it with a towel leaves it dry to the touch. Hopefully there are no problems with the knot coming lose. So far, I don't suspect there will be.<br /><br />As far as I'm concerned, this brush is perfect for how it is used by many people. It is a good first brush for people just getting into wet shaving whether DE or straight. Once you're sure that this is going to be your permanent shave routine, then go ahead and experiment with some more expensive options out there.
  1230. This is a great brush for beginning and/or budget-conscious wetshavers. I highly recommend this as a starter brush, since starting out into the world of wetshaving can be a surprisingly expensive endeavor. This brush is a great option because it allows you to experience using a badger hair brush without having to experience the $50+ cost of most quality badger brushes. While you'll notice a difference in quality between this and a more expensive brush almost immediately, this brush still makes a good lather and outperforms both of the synthetic brushes I own.<br />If you're new to wetshaving, get this for your first brush. It will ease the financial hurt of the transition and will remove some of the sting if you decide to abandon it later on. If you already have some experience, there are much better brushes out there, but this could be a useful travel brush that wouldn't bring on a panic attack if you were to lose it. Whatever your experience level, though, for a badger hair brush you simply can't find a better price than this.
  1231. Not a bad brush. This was the first brush I purchased when I went from the canned stuff to lathering with a brush and mug. It shed a few hairs at first but not that much.   1232. This brush came up first in the search and is popular because it is inexpensive and works well enough, so it's the one I bought. I gave it one star not because of the brush itself, but because of treatment of badgers in China to get this hair. Had I researched first, I would never have bought any badger brush, I would have bought synthetic. I won't say what I learned, because I don't want my review to be offensive. I'll just say that if you're an animal friendly person, you may want to spend five minutes researching the source of badger hair before choosing to support this process with your purchase. I wish I had.
  1233. I recently decided to purchase a brush to improve the quality of my shaves. I've been using the Tweezerman on a daily basis for about a month and I'm very pleased with it. The brush works the lather into my facial hair, allowing for a much closer shave than applying lather by hand. The bristles seem to be of decent quality and the brush works well to create lather from gels and water, or simply spreading canned shaving cream.<br /><br />As many other reviewers have noted, when I began using the brush it seemed that I was losing an excessive number of bristles each time I shaved. I become more diligent about gently squeezing water from the bristles and fanning them before hanging the brush to dry and the bristle loss stopped after about two weeks. The initial loss does not appear to have affected the fullness of the brush.<br /><br />I would definitely recommend the Tweezerman to anyone curious about how a brush can contribute to a better shave.

It is very soft and whips up a creamy lather very fast. I'm coming from a really junky $3 boar brush I got from a local beauty supply, I'd have to spend 10 minutes whipping lather and putting elbow grease into it like I was the karate kid. With this Tweezerman it's so fast and easy. Wet it, whip the water off, make frothy lather in about a minute. Feels really great on the face, too.<br /><br />I can't recommend this as a gift, especially not for a first-timer, because when you first use this thing it really (I mean really) sheds.   1240. 4 Month Review -After switching from Mach III razors<br /><br />Below is the listed product I am using as part of my &#34;Shaving Arsenal.&#34; It took me a while to find each piece needed to bring it all together. My approach was finding all the pieces that had the best reviews vs. price. Just about everything listed below was the &#34;highest price&#34; but luckily these items don't cost much. Not CLOSE to as much as it costs to shave with Mach III Safety razors. If your ready to make the switch to a superior, and cheaper, alternative then check out the products below.<br /><br />Brush: Not sure why its made of &#34;Badger&#34; hair but its working. Where this brush looses a star is because it lost some of its bristles during the first week. Since then there haven't been any more hair-loss and I've had no problems. 4 months going strong. It creates a nice lather and feels good against the skin. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000G647Y8/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_47<br /><br />Handle: Merkur Model 180 Long Handled Safety Razor.<br />The first thing I noticed about this handle is the quality. You can tell its not your basic cheap piece of metal. Its got a comfortable weight to it, keeps its brilliant chrome finish, and clean up is quick and easy. I consider myself a man with normal size hands and don't know why this one is considered &#34;long handled.&#34; Its just a tad longer than the Mach III razor I used to use. However, it’s a night and day difference compared to those &#34;Safety razors.&#34; It cuts very close with minimal passes. I've never had a shave that was this close before.<br />http://www.amazon.com/Merkur-Model-180-Handled-Safety/dp/B000NL0T1G/ref=sr_1_10?ie=UTF8&qid=1355613524&sr=8-10&keywords=double+edge+razor+handle<br /><br />Blades: 7a.m. Platinum Double Edge Safety Razor Blades<br /> I've heard there are better blades on the Market but since I started out with a 100-pack it will be 2-YEARS until I need to buy any more since I change them out once a week. I'm half Filipino so I don't have the thickest facial hair but definably pull off a goatee without a problem. Other than one &#34;Dud&#34; all other blades have been very predictable and easy to use. I have gotten the occasional razor burn but that appears to be normal with any Double-edged razor. I was worried I would be opening myself up to more &#34;risk&#34; with these but feel that I am at no more risk than any other safety blade now that I am used to it.<br />http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0017ZECA6/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_32<br /><br />Stand: Safety Razor stand<br /> Once I learned that a stand was needed for the &#34;Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush&#34; I decided to go with this one. Its been 4 months and the chrome is still shining well. Its sturdy, and holds my double edged razor as well as the shaving brush as if this product was made just for them. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001XURHNY/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_42<br /><br />Shaving Soap: Prosaro Shaving Soap<br />It works but I with it had more lather. Based on previous reviews, it sounds like the amount of lather has significantly decreased. Does it work? Yes, but I like a good lather. Anyways, its been 3 months and I feel like I have maybe gone through half of this container which isn't bad. It also has a very fresh but subtle smell which I really like.<br />http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00837YY18/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_44?ie=UTF8&redirect=true<br /><br />Soap Bowl: Guess I didn't need this since I am using the Proraso Shaving Soap which is self contained. For as simple as it is, it lost two stars. There is a rim that goes along the bottom that has (or had) a black rubber piece that ran around it to provide a good footing for the Bowl while on a counter. The very first day this part fell off, it didn’t seat on there, and it wasn't glued. In the garbage that piece went. The next star was lost due to finish. It was a pretty flat finish for chrome and you could see theseveral light scratches across it. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00404RI70/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_35<br /><br />After Shave: Virgin Island Bay Rum by Clubman<br />I've tested several types of Aftershave in stores but never found anything I liked. Based on reviews I had a hunch I would really like this. Once it arrived I was right! It gives me a very fresh feeling after my morning shave, and has an amazing smell which isn't overpowering at all. My wife is very sensitive to smells but this is one she actually admires.<br />http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000053L6W/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_2several light scratches across it. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00404RI70/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_35<br /><br />After Shave: Virgin Island Bay Rum by Clubman<br />I've tested several types of Aftershave in stores but never found anything I liked. The brush is no better or worse than any low-cost brush I have used. If you buy based on his review, which is very encouraging, then don't be surprised if you find the hairs on your face and left behind on the soap.   1259. This shaving brush lathers soap incredibly well and without fault.   1274. Not bad for a budget boar hair brush. First couple of times you use it you will loose some hairs, but that is to be expected. Rinse it out thoroughly, and air dry it hanging w/the hairs down and I don't see why this would not last someone quite a while.
  1275. I really like this brush and for the price, I think anyone who shaves should have this at least as a travel or back-up brush. For me, this is my primary. Nice bristles, feel good against the skin. Very soft and smooth. The only thing is that it's a little small for my hands and so I have to really get it rolling to build a great lather. Have about 10 shaves on it and have seen maybe a grand total of 5-10 bristles in my bowl afterwards. Another reviewer had correctly pointed out that proper brush care is vital to the health of your brush. I was fortunate in that my grandpa taught me wet-shaving when I was about 14 or so and a big part of his lectures was on brush and metal maintenance. Never mash your brush into the bowl, always keep it moving and in the same direction as much as possible, before going in the opposite direction to churn, never dry by flicking, dry it by lightly running the brush in one direction in your palm and then spreading the bristles before you hang it to dry. I have a great stand and this fits perfectly on it. I can see this lasting a few decades.
  1276. Like others I noticed the brush smells bad when wet. The smell did not make his face smell bad. The first couple of uses it lost some hair but that has stopped. This brush is much softer than his boar brush and for the price it is ok. Not sure I would buy this one again but I might recommend it to a beginner.

  1310. I ordered the Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush for my husband's birthday, April 2012. (His first shaving brush.) My husband shaves about once a week, and had no problems until about 2 months worth of use. The brush sits (in the stand) on the bathroom counter, and while cleaning, I lightly bumped it and the \\"ball\\" of dry bristles fell out of the wooden stand. The ball of bristles were attached to the stand using some kind of wax. Anyway my husband used krazy glue to reattach it, and got maybe 2 more uses and it the bristles fell out again. Each time the brush is used, my husband takes care to thourghly rise the it and place it back in the brush stand to dry. The ball of bristles were glued with a bit more krazy glue a second time, and thankfully it has not fallen out since.<br /><br />I thought the $12.09 I paid for this brush was a really good deal, and based on all the excellent reviews, I did not expect this sort of thing to happen. There are however several reviewers stating the bristles fell out, as well as other complaints. All in all, I would NOT recommend this brush. I suggest spending a little more money on a better badger brush and not have the hassle of reattaching the bristles to the stand. OR if you do buy this brush, don't expect it to last forever!

Wish Old Spice would start making them again. I'm using the Gillette Fusion Hydro Gel and razor. It wasn't working real well for me. But with this brush, problem solved. Now I take the lather and smear some on my face, wet the brush with hot water and work it in. It not only builds a better lather it feels great and the razor burn is gone again.
