  1318. I have a 15 year old brush that I was replacing with this new brush. One attempted use convinced me to return this product and continue using my old brush.
  1319. my husband is happy with this
  1320. Love this brush. Makes applying creams and shaving a breeze. Thanks for your great product!! Recommend this brush for first time shavers.
  1321. You get what you pay for, the price is right, the brush is stored in brush hanger but it still starts falling apart after a couple of uses.
  1322. First off, for the price, it can't be beat. Is if far from perfect? Yes. Here's why:<br /><br />It smells like a badger out of the box. Its not a terrible smell, but its not exactly something I wanted to smell like. Fortunately, I shave at night when I have time to take some time and enjoy the process so the smell on my face was gone by the morning. If you use it with a scented shave soap the smell will be gone in a week. Mine was gone faster because I practiced whipping up a lather 2-3 times a day for a few days to break the brush in and to get the hang of the technique.<br /><br />It takes a week or two to break in. It felt pretty awful on the first use. I soak it for 5-10 minutes before every use (while I shower) and on the first few uses, it felt like the tips of the hairs were stabbing my face. Not pleasant. With about two weeks of use, this has improved greatly and it has become comfortable with that right amount of scrubbing feeling that lets you know the lather is getting around the base of every hair and cleaning all the gunk off your face.<br /><br />It loses bristles a lot in the first week. One of the reviews said that you shouldn't use the handle when whipping up your soap, but with my bowl that I use this is not possible. I'm not going to caress this cheap brush as if it was my first child, I'm going to use it like the tool that it is. As long as you dry it with the bristles down on a stand (just buy a stand if you don't have one, it functions nice, looks nice and makes your shaving things look like a set) the hairs will stop falling out after about a week and you'll be left with a nice brush that should last for a while.<br /><br />Summary: Three stars may seem low, but the breaking in process warrants that. Five stars goes to a product that blows my mind and lasts forever. This will not. It is, however, a great value and good for beginners.
  1323. Okay, so I just got into the whole wet shaving thing pretty recently, and I wanted to start off with an inexpensive, decent brush. Based on the majority of the reviews, this seemed like the brush for me, so I went ahead and got it despite a few misgivings. Here's the problem though, if the good reviewers actually have a good brush, then Tweezerman has a real quality management problem because mine starting falling apart pretty much immediately (and if you do some more research you'll find out I'm far from the only one).<br /><br />...But let's start on a positive note. The brush itself actually does a pretty nice job--especially considering the fact it's a $10 brush. It definitely performs above its price range! However, I've lost at least 30 hairs out of the thing so far, and that number's likely to go up drastically in the fairly near future (see next paragraph for details). Oh, I take great care of my things, so the hair loss isn't coming from any sort of misuse or neglect.<br /><br />Now for the good part...the handle. First of all, the people at Tweezerman must be mentally retarded making a brush handle out of wood for a piece of equipment that is regularly near and/or submerged in water. It's fairly obvious to anyone with basic common sense that eventually the wood will break down, and most people who have used this brush eventually run into this problem somewhere down the line. Once again, I fall victim to terrible quality management in that mine began to crack within a week! Not just tiny little cracks either...I have many cracks in my handle, including a giant freaking crack running down the base and side of my brush. Don't ask me how this even happened because outside of cleaning the brush the handle's never even gotten wet or partially submerged for a prolonged period of time.<br /><br />I honestly feel this brush is such a waste of my time that I'm not even bothering to return it...I'm going to use it till it falls apart, then I'm going to doexactly what I suggest you all do...instead of buying this piece of junk go out and spend $40+ for a nice brush that's going to last you a much longer time. There are plenty of great shaving brushes for all budgets...whether you're looking to spend $200+ or $30, so pass this one up and fork over an extra $20 or so if you're looking for a budget brush. Believe me, you will not regret it.<br /><br />I accept that I got a poorly made brush, and that there are probably plenty of these brushes that don't fall apart in the matter of weeks, but it's just too much frustration and annoyance to deal with for $10. Whether it's in a week or two or several years, this brush will fall apart due to poor workmanship and design choices, and I just don't think that's acceptable regardless of cost.
  1324. Bought this brush based on a good reviews I read here, to replace my old shaving brush that I bought from Wal-Mart for $10. I did not have supper high expectations but expected it to be at least comparable to the one I had. Well… I was disappointed. The bristles on this brush are too short to get a good foam or gel on your face with comfort. Shaving with this brush was very unpleasant experience so I threw it away and got another one that I am finding acceptable from Wal-Mart.
  1325. I have used this brush daily for 2 months. There are some hairs that fall out here and there but nothing majoe. Holds up well, and I would suggest getting a stand for this brush to hang upside down. That way water won't run down and losen the glue holding the hair inside the brush. Brushes will last longer.
  1326. This is a great brush but any good brush goes bad if you don't store it correctly. Make sure that you buy a stand to keep your brush upside down when note in use otherwise the brush will go for a toss very soon. I bought &#34;Colonel Conk No.134 Acrylic Brush Stand&#34; along with this brush and both have been working great. The stand is a bit smaller for this brush but I am able to still manage it ok.
  1327. Good first brush. It did shed some hair for the first two weeks, but not a problem anymore. Since I don't have anything to compare it to, I don't think I can give it a 5 star rating. I feel like it should be able to hold heat a bit better than it does, but I won't bump it down a star because of this (again, first brush, so can't compare it to anything else yet).
  1328. This brush is an incredible brush, especially for the price! It rivals the more expensive badger brushes at the price of a boar hair brush. It is also very durable, doesn't shed, and has a lifetime warranty.
  1329. my partner loved it - perfect gift for him to go with all the accessories . . . . .
  1330. Bought this brush to test the waters of wet shaving, and it was a good purchase for the price. I've had it for about 3 months, and it has mostly stopped shedding (the first two weeks or so it lost several hairs each shave), with only a hair or two lost every other shave. Feels great, don't know how to compare it as I have not had a boar or silvertip brush. Plan on keeping this until some excess of money allows me to buy a silvertip from whippeddog.com but this is a good choice for someone who is just getting started
  1331. I have been updating my grooming habits recently using shaving brush, pre-shave oil (organic) and, of course, shaving soap (organic, too). I updated to this brush from the one in kit sold at my local ****-mart store.<br /><br />Right off you feel and see the difference while spreading the shaving soap, cream in my case. It is NOT messy, but evenly covered. The bristles are soft on skin. The old one used to poke me.<br /><br />Since this is my first brush (or second one, actually) I will have to give update based on durability. I read that these brushes tend to, or may lose their shape. A brush holder is recommended to maintain their shape; I am looking for one now.
  1332. New to wet shaving last year and after reading too many reviews, I decided to do my own comparison of shaving brushes. I purchased this brush and a Van Der Hagen brush in July 2014. The Van Der Hagen brush is stiff and takes a long time to generate a good lather. The Tweezerman brush is soft and generates a lather quickly. I use the Tweezerman brush on a daily basis and keep the Van Der Hagen brush in my travel bag where it gets occasional use.
  1333. New to the DE thing so went lower end on the brush. For the price it's great, had several hairs fall out first use. Feels good, holds water, and does the job. I will be upgrading though in the future
  1334. Price cannot be beat on this brush. This was my second brush purchase and leaps and bounds ahead of the synthetic brush my gf had picked out for me.<br /><br />That being said, it definitely had a badger smell when I first began using it. After the first 2-3 shaves the brush picked up the smell of my Proraso shaving soap and has not been an issue since.<br /><br />Brush feels great on the face and lathers extremely well. Have been using it 3-4 times a week for almost a year and have not had issues with a cracked handle like some others here. The brush will occasionally lose bristles, will occasionally find a few in my shaving soap but it's maybe 2-3 bristles a month so nothing really to worry about given the price of the brush.<br /><br />Have bought as a gift for friends starting wet shaving and they've all had similar experiences. Great first time brush but looking to try a whippeddog.com silvertip in the future since it's not much more money and a much nicer brush.
  1335. For the price I was expecting something nasty, but based on reviews I tried it. Wonderful. It's not awesome but its very good and I've been using it for a couple months. Never lost more than a few bristles and I use a brush like a tool in the bowl... I mash and flash. I do clean and put in a stand which is crucial for brushes IMHO. This is a nice brush whether its a main or travel. Don't be fooled by the price like I almost was.
  1336. I've been using the lowest end Walmart shaving brushes before I got this one and it's a major improvement. Lathers well and after six months of daily use it still feels like new. Good value for the price.
  1337. Works ok for the price, but it is kind of prickly. Fine for a starter badger brush.

  1339. Great product, have had mine for years and am just writing this review now. It will likely last a lifetime.
  1340. This is a good quality brush, but it was much smaller than I expected it to be. I went back to using my older brush. Still, a good brush for the money.

  1342. This was my first brush when I decided to get into safety razor shaving. This brush has worked very well for me. I have recommended this brush to other beginner safety razor shavers and they have all loved it as well.
